characters: "GLIS WAS VERY FRAPPER. SHE HAD DENARPEN FARFIE'S
POLAROID PHOTO/DEAD GANG MEMBER IN CASKET

dialogues.speaker: RUSH HOUR
dialogues.text: ON a pair of black Dexter penny loafers diligently pedaling an old Schwinn mountain bike. ADJUST ANGLE now to meet the bicyclist... He's African-American. Anywhere from 33 to 40. Wears wire-rim glasses, a fresh white oxford shirt, creased slacks and a solid green tie. An unobtrusive figure, at once familiar and yet undiscerning. The type you'd pass on a sidewalk and never even notice. He's TREVOR GARFIELD ADJUST ANGLE FURTHER now to reveal the upper promenade bike path and a dramatic view of Lower Manhattan behind him. Morning sun glimmers off the Trade Center towers. Trevor's shadow skitters along the wooden path, 160 ft. above the East River. A fat briefcase, strapped to the back of his bike, rocks back and forth as he pumps the pedals. FROM ABOVE now a sweeping view of Trevor, alone on the bike path, a speck, suspended above a sea of rush hour traffic on the bridge below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wrought-iron train trestle covered with graffiti shakes as an "EL" TRAIN ROARS overhead. Trevor races parallel with it along Atlantic Avenue. Every city block becomes more and more rundown.

dialogues.speaker: STUYVESANT
dialogues.text: A cyclone fence frames the stalwart face of the old three-story administration building. Ubiquitous gray patches of paint fail to cover where taggers have most recently left their marks. The ASSISTANT PRINCIPAL, a black man with a booming voice, barks at late-comers who are about to be tardy...

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: (clapping his hands) .-. Let's go, people! Tardy lock- out starts in one minute! Get your butts in gear! One minute, people! Move it! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OCTOBER 1994
dialogues.text: The Assistant Principal, attention diverted, doesn't even notice Trevor as he enters on his bike and races down the sidewalk in front of the school. With all the prompting, students still don't seem to be in much of a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as Trevor squeezes through the doorway past students being processed through card readers and metal detectors and turns down the main hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a glance over his shoulder, Trevor hops back onto his bike and pedals it down the middle of the corridor. STRAGGLING STUDENTS either ignore him or look at him like he's insane.

dialogues.speaker: STRAGGLING STUDENT
dialogues.text: (as Trevor passes) .--- No ridin' bikes in ‘a hallway, stoo-pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trevor reaches the end of the main corridor... and steers his bike down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor coasts skillfully down the stairs and emerges onto the bottom floor of the school. He pedals away toward the other end of the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of 10th graders loiter outside Trevor's room. Seeing him coming, they stir to life with a flurry of taunts. Trevor chooses to face all dissension with a smile. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Trevor hops off his bike and unlocks the classroom door, he notices two lovers making out in the hallway...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE IN CROWD
dialogues.text: .-. Yuh late, Garfield.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (catching his breath) +. No, bell hasn't rung yet. Okay, let's get inside. C'mon. (as they file into the room) .-. Morning, morning. Rise and shine. TWO STUDENTS make passing comments...

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) +. You one crazy-ass nigga, G.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: (a quarter stuck in one ear) .-. Damn skippy.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Thank you for sharing, Auggie.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: (provoking Auggie) «+. Auggie doggie.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Tywan. Yer mama's a gangsta-rapper. Trevor offers a pleasant greeting to the two lovers.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me, you two... this isn't the Playboy Channel. Trevor enters the room, but ducks his head back into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ‘Morning, Juanita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walls are covered with assorted science posters. Styrofoam nuclei dangle from the ceiling. Trevor unstraps the fat briefcase from his bicycle and sets it on a metal stool next to his desk... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Let's get started. August and Tywan, you pass out the books. Thank you, gentlemen. Auggie and Tywan don't budge.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: Whas up wit' your car, G? Yer Pinto blow up? The majority of students aren't even paying attention. A group in the back is already starting a card game.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (good-natured smile) No, I don't own a Pinto, Tywan. (addressing the class) Okay, can I have everyone's attention? No response, but it doesn't phase Trevor. He removes the front wheels from his bike.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: The purpose of the bicycle is to demonstrate the principle of centripetal force. That's the opposite of the force we studied yesterday, which was...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE IN THE CROWD
dialogues.text: Magnum force. Hoots and laughter.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Centrifugal force... Centripetal force is where the acceleration of a body moving in circular motion is directed toward its center by an opposing force, thus creating momentum that constrains the body to its circular path. Like a gyroscope. (sees nothing but yawns) It's better if I show you. Here, Tywan, you be my helper. Tywan and Auggie are busy talking in the corner. They still haven't passed out the books. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Tywan? Come on. Tywan, solidly built like a Rodin bronze, saunters over.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: Whad-up, G? (to rest of class) Hey, shut up! Y'all too damn loud, man! Class quiets but only marginally.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I need you to demonstrate centripetal force. (removes briefcase from stool) Here, have a seat. Tywan sits and Trevor hands him the upside-down bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, hold the bike steady with your knees. That's it. Seat positioned against your chest. Tywan glances over at Auggie and starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: (to Auggie) Shut up, foo.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, now crank the pedals and get that back wheel spinning about 180 R.P.M.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: Whas up wit' dat?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (coaxing him along) You'll see. Be patient. A skeptical Tywan starts to crank the pedals, but he's not pedaling hard enough.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: -+. Put some muscle into it. Tywan cranks the pedals harder now. Trevor back-pedals over to the textbook shelf and randomly selects a physical science book (but doesn't open it). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-. Keep pedaling. Harder. A paper airplane sails past an oblivious Tywan. He cranks harder and harder until he's sweating ham juice. Now, he impales Trevor with a befuddled squint.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: (incredulous ) Whas up? I tol' you you was crazy, man. A thin smile of confidence from Trevor now...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Now tilt the wheel to your right. Tywan does and immediately the wheel pulls him to the right, causing the stool to slowly spin on its axis.

dialogues.speaker: TYWAN
dialogues.text: (eyes wide like a little kid) Aw, damn. I'm spinnin'. Lookit me, Auggie! Trevor flickers a smile as Tywan's spinning starts to draw the attention of the rest of the class. Now Trevor refers to the physical science book in his hand. Smile on his face immediately fades. INSERT: Physical science textbook. In magic marker. The large number 187 has been scrawled across every page. Trevor flips through the book. He checks the front page to see who it belongs to. Juxtaposed to Trevor's distracted state, the class is now focused on Tywan's achievement...

dialogues.speaker: CLASS
dialogues.text: (attempting unison) .»-. Tywan, Tywan, Tywan.

dialogues.speaker: PERIOD
dialogues.text: One of the fluorescent lights overhead flickers. The place is deserted except for a custodian who pushes a cresting wave of trash ahead of his broom. Now Trevor heads up the north stairwell at the far end of the corridor. He clutches the desecrated physical science book. A student slides down the banister past him.  10 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PUERTO RICAN WOMAN prods a group of gangbanger wanna- bes. Two of the teens hover over a Sony Walkman, sharing the earphones.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Okay, fellas, off the table. Put the Walkman away. I said put it away... A 10th grade counselor's office opens and a student emerges. Trevor walks directly in.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Walter, I need to speak with you. WALTER (Anglo; 52) is a disheveled middle-aged counselor. A lifer. He chews on an empty smoking pipe as he glances through a student "cum" (cue-mm).

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) I'm pretty busy right now, Garfield. What is it? Trevor sets the book down on Walter's desk and nervously adjusts his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Could you open it, please? Walter opens the book.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (a weary look of disgust) Don't suppose this kid cares about our budget crisis? (shuts the book) Have the textbook room charge him for the book. Walter snaps the book shut and looks up at Trevor. That's all?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: One-Eight-Seven is a penal code number for murder, Walter. Means the same thing as T-O-S. ‘Terminate On the Spot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (piqued) For chrissake, I know what it stands for. Look, kid probably heard it in a rap song. Doesn't mean anything.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. The book belongs to Dennis Broadway. He's a known gangster, Walter -- a 'Five Percenter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Garfield, if I had a dollar for every time a student threatened faculty... Don't you think you're overreacting a little?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (suppressing trepidation) Did you tell Dennis Broadway he was getting a fail from me?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (stymied) I have legal access to those files.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: He's a transfer from Nixon High School, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (becoming defensive) Look, I'm not obligated to track you down every time a transfer student comes through here. You want confidential information like that, come look it up in his cum (cue-mm). Trevor exhales a sigh of resignation.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Do you have him on a contract?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: If he gets through the semester without a fail then he gets to go back to Nixon, so what?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. and be with his homeboys. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walter's caught between a rock and a hard place. His instincts lean toward self-preservation.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So he blew his opportunity. Now he has to learn to live with the consequences.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I don't think this kid's ready to deal with the consequences. I think he wants me dead.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Relax, has nothin' to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I should have been told, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm on your side, Garfield, but my hands are tied. Kid has a right to his privacy... Know what your problem is? You're an idealist.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You only see what you wanna see, that's what's wrong. On one hand you think someone's trying to kill you. On the other hand you actually believe kids are paying attention in your classes. Trevor resigns himself to the fact that he's come to the wrong person for support.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (collecting himself) Never mind. It's not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (an empty promise) Tell you what, as soon as I get a chance I'll summons the kid. Promise. Trevor's bemusement holds us.  12 13 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor retraces his steps back up the empty corridor as the passing BELL RINGS. Within seconds the corridor is teeming with teenagers. Into SLOW MOTION now. MANEUVERING THROUGH the crowd to DISCOVER DENNIS BROADWAY (16). About ten paces behind. His Snoop-Dogg Afro frames a gold earring and a pair of deep-set eyes filled with vitriol. Oblivious of Dennis, Trevor presses on toward the north stairwell. VARIOUS SHOTS OVERHEAD and THROUGH crowd as the gap between Dennis and Trevor narrows. Every facial expression, every blink of an eye, all magnified a hundred times. Broadway's right hand is wrapped in a dirty white handkerchief as he reaches into the front pocket of his baggie Solos and pulls out a block of wood with a ten-penny nail imbedded in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor's heavy eyelids blink as he slowly glances up into a parabolic mirror on the wall. A silent, paroxysmal terror registers on his face. In a parabolic mirror, the blurred image of Dennis Broadway, pushing hard toward a conclusion now. BACK TO SPEED as Dennis explodes forward, body blocking Trevor from behind, pinning him against a wall and sending the "187" textbook flying. He rams his weapon into Trevor's back. In a SERIES OF RAPID-FIRE CUTS, filtered sunlight shimmers off the sharpened nail as it slashes downward. A barrage of stabbing motions, tearing at cloth and flesh. Trevor's backward flailing arms are ineffective in blocking the frenzied stabfest. Downward slashing, again and again... 10 times. Aftermath. As quickly as it began it's over. Dennis Broadway slams open an exit door and is gone. Students scatter like cockroaches. An eerie stillness lingers. Trevor Garfield is lying on his back now in a pool of blood; black plastic framed glasses in pieces on the floor; lifeless arms spread out at his sides. His rheumy, unblinking eyes stare upward into infinite space. Breathing is the major focus of his concentration now as we SLOWLY MOVE IN ON his face. HOLD and now...  14 15 16 17 11.

dialogues.speaker: SEVENTEEN MONTHS LATER
dialogues.text: It's a tiny one bedroom house in the East San Fernando Valley. A chain-link fence surrounds the perimeter and a large olive tree shades the neatly-mowed front lawn. And in the back there's a wooden tool shed that borders a narrow alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the predawn light a terra cotta angel stands guard over a bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stillness. Now the PHONE RINGS. A shape in the bed stirs. A desk lamp flickers on, illuminating the phone. Trevor's hand reaches for the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Morning...

dialogues.speaker: SUB UNIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Morning, Mr. Garfield. This is the Sub Unit. Are you available for work?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat) »-.- Yes, uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: SUB UNIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's a science class in the Valley at John Quincy Adams. It's a four day assignment. Teacher's name is Eskander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear what God hears over the following...

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: Trevor hangs his head under a torrent of soothing water.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: Ceremoniously, he irons a shirt... and polishes his shoes, a broad scar shows across the back of his hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: His pressed slacks and tie hang meticulously over a chair as he gets dressed.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: Now Jesus Christ looks down on Trevor from his crucifix on the bedroom wall.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (kneeling bedside) +. If you're listening, God, please help me today. All I ask is a chance to do my job... t'do the job you put me here to do in the first place. (prayerfully now) Please help me accept those things I cannot change... and give me strength to change those things I can. (beat) .-. This is me, Trevor, God. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: "A" BUILDING
dialogues.text: Traffic bottle-necks as students cross in front of cars, and big yellow L.A.U.S.D. buses pull in. The green lawn is scattered with students (about 65% Hispanic). Compared to the scarred, institutional look of Roosevelt Whitney, the face of John Quincy Adams is unblemished. (This is your own backyard, not the inner city) Sagging pants (Dickies, Ben Davis) and oversized jackets (County Bens, Duke, Georgetown) are represented. The different socio-economic and ethnic groups stick with their own kind; the IHPs (Individual Honors Program), the taggers, the Gangbangers, the Asians, the Armenians...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anglo boy, Stevie Littleton, gets out of his mom's Lexus in the school parking lot and walks towards school.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Trevor sits behind the wheel of his Rambler. Watches a passing parade of students with detachment.  20 21 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 13.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: Trevor, fat briefcase in hand, crosses the front lawn. He's not the same Trevor we met back in Bedford- Stuvyesant. Withdrawn, guarded, he manufactures a cautious smile at students in passing. Trevor now approaches VICTOR SIFUENTES, a young plain- clothes narc, who intermittently wands students with a metal detector at the front doors. FAVOR a kid now who wears a baseball cap with an emblem on the crown that says "Fucd."

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: .-. Baseball cap, give it up. The kid grudgingly reciprocates, handing over his cap.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (stopping Trevor now) Hold it, please. Trevor produces his blue employee card.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I'm a substitute.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (pointing) Okay, you want the Main Office, straight ahead. Check in with Mrs. Ford.

dialogues.speaker: BEFORE FIRST PERIOD
dialogues.text: Trevor wanders up the crowded corridor. Along with his briefcase he now carries a sub folder that contains a homeroom roster, lesson plans and seating charts. A sporadic row of teachers, like weary sentinels, stand outside their classrooms. TEACHER #1 is an insipid woman in her mid-forties. She's overweight and wears too much make-up.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: --. ‘Scuse me. I'm lost. I'm looking for Bungalow... (checks homeroom roster) «+. eighty-six. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (pointing) All the way out, next to the parking lot. Last bungalow on the left.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (fatalistic) Good luck. Her comment weighs on him as he resumes his winding path through the bustle of students headed for first period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing through open doorways. Observing the inner life of various classrooms in passing... sees students watch- ing TV, teacher ignores them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLO MALE, 39, slouching behind his desk, attempting to read a newspaper but distracted by an offstage commotion.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: (erupting) --. Sit down. I come back there and you're gonna be sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the opposite side of the corridor... we can hear Ellen Henry's voice before reaching her doorway. All brightness and light, full of enthusiasm...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (like, a buzzer; times up) +. EEEEgghh! Wrong. William, you know this. C'mon, how do you find the pound sign? What's the fastest way? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now we see her through the doorway. ELLEN HENRY (TEACHER #3). She's thirty, Anglo, and non-tenured. At the front of the class ten students stand linked together, arm-in- arm, in a human chain. WILLIAM (15) sits behind a compute in the front row struggling to decipher the problem...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (playfully) You're not thinking. (a major clue) How ‘bout Binary search. William remains puzzled. The chain of students delight in chiding him. "C'mon, Beavis!"...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (the answer) You split them! Ellen attempts to bisect the impulsive chain of students with a double-handed karate chop. Fickle chain that they are, they resist.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (amused) ... Very funny. Now a SLOW MOTION fleeting moment as she catches Trevor's passing gaze and openly smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor rinses his face at the sink as Victor Sifuentes’ head speaks to him from above one of the heavily graffitied stalls in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: So who yuh here for?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Eskander.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (zipping up, exiting) Aw, man, you got bungalow duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a MEANDERING COURSE, MERGING with Trevor now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Increasing evidence of tagging, and bands of wandering students, indicate a higher degree of disorder the further one gets from the Main Office. FROM ABOVE NOW, like Algernon and his maze, Trevor negotiates his own path deeper and deeper into the configuration of bungalows. .-. And Trevor's trepidation. Eyes discerning every passerby. His PULSE AUDIBLY RACES, senses heightened. SHIFTING INTO SLOW MOTION AGAIN... And the reverberating SOUND of a SPRAY PAINT MARBLE as Trevor rounds a corner and comes face to face with three tag-bangers concealing spray paint cans inside their oversized jackets. One of the taggers locks eyes with Trevor as he passes, a slow premonitory burn. The tagger has a "skin tight" (pelon) hair cut and a string of black rosary beads around his neck. A barcode tattoo on the back of his neck identi- fies BENNY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-. Behind the bungalows, adjacent the delivery gate. Meet DAVE CHILDRESS, a forty-something ditto-head. The residual effects of a hangover linger as he sneaks a cigarette before first period. He wears a faded Hawaiian shirt and Huarache sandals. An old military tattoo emblazons his left forearm. As he crushes out his cigarette, something catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+. Thru a chain-link fence we see a handful of cholo- types loitering around the shed. Childress investigates. As he approaches the fence...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: ... Hey, ese(s)?! Homeboys scatter in all directions, some hop the chain- link fence, others scurry out a narrow gate behind the shed. Childress weighs an amused smirk. Now out of nowhere a gangbanger lurches from the shed, buttoning his sagging Dickies and tripping over his own feet. He scrambles out the back gate and is gone. Childress, curiosity piqued, now enters the compound through a tear in the fence.  29 30 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Childress pokes his head inside he discovers... Rita Nartinez, seventeen... braless. A niobium belly- ring piercing her navel. She pulls a dark blue sweat shirt on over her head. Glances up at Childress. Masks her shame with a defiant smirk. (Behind the heavy eyeliner and baggy pants of a chola, Rita's really nothing more than a little lost girl.)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (knowing full well) What the hell's going on here, lil' sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor flicks on the lights, exposing bare, colorless walls and closed venetian blinds. His breathing's slightly labored as he sets down his briefcase. His back faces the mob of students that trickle in now as he takes a surreptitious hit off an inhaler. Almost instantly his breathing returns to normal. Now he shuts his eyes and prepares to conjure up the dormant enthusiasm he used to have. Takes a deep cathartic breath. Now he digs a file folder out of his briefcase, opens it, selects a dispatch and approaches the blackboard. BELL RINGS as he picks up a piece of chalk... and begins. First he writes his name in the corner of the blackboard. Now he moves to the center of the blackboard and begins to write per the file folder in his hand...

dialogues.speaker: MARDSEN..."
dialogues.text: No one pays much attention. Back still facing the class...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: +. Before taking roll, I'd like to prove a point. Now one or two students begin to notice the indecipherable gibberish he is writing on the board... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARSEK
dialogues.text: (Armenian; a disparaging laugh) ‘Farfie?' (cholo-like) Whad up, Farfie? Trevor mentally blocks out the salvo of grunts, groans and expletives. With each subsequent stroke of the chalk he is exorcising his demons...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. It's not important what... or who... 'Farfie' is. Turning to face the class now...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yuh wanna play, yuh gotta stay. Have a seat, please. A handful of students take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pacing now) The point I'd like to make is this... Anyone here can be a scientist. «+. a grudging buzz of confusion.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN GIRL
dialogues.text: (sotto; puzzled) .-. What's he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: --. A scientist is like a detective. He investigates data. He scratches the surface of things he doesn't understand to see what's underneath. (pointing to blackboard) .+. Things like this. Okay, who wants to read? Barsek (the class clown) breaks in...

dialogues.speaker: BARSEK
dialogues.text: (standing up) I'll do it. Trevor quiets a harmless barrage of, "Bart," "sit down" and "Armenian Power sucks"... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Come on, we don't need disrespect. Let ‘im do it. (to Barsek) What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: BARSEK
dialogues.text: Barsek. A wisp of gratification flickers at the corner of Trevor's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, Barsek. Read. (The following is read in fits and starts and accompanied by diminishing laughter and ridicule.)

dialogues.speaker: BARSEK
dialogues.text: -.. Glis was very frapper. She had denarpen Farfie's Mardsen. She couldn't galp a giberter for Farfie. Instead she wharked to plimp a mardsen binky for him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, anyone know what Barsek just said? .-. A unanimous "No." Trevor can see the light at the end of the tunnel now. He's back in the zone.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: That's alright. You don't need to understand something to answer a few simple questions about it. Every one of you is capable of decoding data. Watch. Trevor writes question #1 on the board...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... Why was Glis Frapper? Can anyone tell me? The Asian Girl, into it now, tentatively raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pointing at Asian Girl) Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Asian Girl's POV as she studies the first two sentences on the board.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN GIRL
dialogues.text: (slowly; cautiously) .-. Glis was frapper... because... she had denarpen Farfie's mardsen?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (understated) That's right. You got it. (reactions all around) Let's try another. Trevor reads and writes question #2 on the board...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: +. What did Glis plimp? Before Trevor can finish writing the question, an unidentified voice blurts out, "He plimped a Ho." Scattered laughter. Trevor grimaces, shakes his head. Now attempts to add the question mark at the end of the sentence but the chalk breaks, causing dissension.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (searching blackboard ledge) .-.- Hold on, hold on. Where's your teacher keep the chalk?

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN GIRL
dialogues.text: ... In the desk. Trevor hastily rifles through the teacher's drawers. A startling discovery abruptly halts his search... CLOSER now INTO a brown paper bag Trevor has opened. Inside the bag is a .357 Magnum. OFF Trevor's narrowing gaze, an offstage voice interrupts...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .»-. Can I help you? Trevor lifts his head to see Dave Childress standing in the doorway of the bungalow. Trevor shuts the desk drawer. You can hear a pin drop. Childress piston-chews a wad of gum as he approaches Trevor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. Had to handle something. You a sub?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (puzzled) I thought this was Science. Ms. Eskander. Childress weighs a shit-eating grin as he glances at Trevor's name on the board.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: No. This is Dave Childress, American History. Some students brave a laugh at Trevor's expense.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: -+. Don't know how to break it to you... (glancing at Trevor's name again) .-.. Garfield... but this is bungalow 84. Childress now places a patronizing hand on Trevor's shoulder and steers him toward the window blinds.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: See, you zigged when you shoulda zagged. Course it's not your fault someone jacked the number off my door. Keep askin' Garcia to fix it but all I get is ‘'nada.' Childress draws the blinds on one of the windows exposing another bungalow across the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --. In complete disarray. Students clutter the doorway as wads of paper intermittently zing past them.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: ... that mess over there, that's Eskander's. OFF Trevor's unflinching stare...  32 33 34 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bungalow was originally designed for lab science: glass-encased cupboards, a caged white lab rat on a side counter, an 8' by 3' counter top (island) at the front of the room, including a built-in sink and butane gas valve. Students crowd the opened windows on the far side of the room. The chaotic atmosphere centers around one student... Benny Chacon (18), the tagger we met earlier. Trevor's back to square one. He struggles with trepidation as he steps into the doorway of the bungalow and hesitates. A young black girl, LAKESIA STEWART (16), stands near the doorway. She cradles a realistic looking E.N.A.B.L. baby (Education Now And Babies Later).

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIA
dialogues.text: You our sub? Trevor takes a peek at the doll.

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIA
dialogues.text: It's not real. We're studying teen parenting in home-ec.' It's computerized, so it cries and shit. Crowd at the windows begins to disperse now, finding their seats, except for Benny who doesn't budge. Trevor approaches, gazes out the window, eyes sizing up the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scattered on the blacktop between the parking lot fence and bungalow #86 are 35 science textbooks.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (addressing Benny; without prejudging) You know how the books got outside? Benny plays with the black rosary around his neck. Responds with mock ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: No speaky Engless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Class erupts with laughter. A wad of paper sails past Trevor and out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You speak Spanish, Mister... Whas yer name?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Garfield.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: -+. You speak Spanish, Mister G? (as Trevor ignores the question) Eh, G... know what dat means when a homeboy calls you 'G'? Dat means gangster, homes. You a gangster, maestro?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No, I'm not a gangster. (beat) Would you please do me a favor and pick up the books?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (xighteous indignation) Andate a la mierda. (more laughs) I ain't pickin’ dat shit up. You go pick it up. Benny now finds a seat. Trevor follows him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Cesar Chavez. Don't you recognize me? Class laughs. Trevor refers to the seating chart (inside the sub folder) in his hand but Benny's not sitting in his proper seat. Benny indicates a 2" by 3" monitoring device strapped to his ankle...

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: See dis? I'm already on house arrest, homes. Ain't nothin' more you can do to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly three students across from Benny (the other three taggers we saw earlier, Cesar Sanchez, Stevie Littleton and Paco) stand with bold impunity. All are 17. Cesar has a buzz-cut, Stevie's an Anglo speed freak with a runny nose and a bleached one-clip haircut (roots showing) and Paco, a Latino.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Sit down, please. Cesar, Stevie and Paco ignore Trevor and walk out of the bungalow. Their departure is accompanied by a tumultuous outburst of catcalls and whistles.

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIA
dialogues.text: (peeking Benny's hold card) Mr. G, those guys that jus' walked out aren't even in here this period. (pointing to Benny) And this fool's name is Benny Chacon.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (whirls in his seat) Shut yer mouth, hood rat! School girl bitch!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, Benny. That's enough. Benny turns his wrath on Trevor now.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Hey, you ain't no real teacher. Fool, you're nothin' but a sub. T'ink yer so cool... You mus' be ‘Mr. culo.' Scattered laughter. Trevor closes the sub folder and just looks at Benny.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (a cool curiosity) Why do you wear a rosary?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (reacting) Ain't none a' yer damn business. To put God on me, okay? Why don't you jus' go sit down and read yer newspaper. Wanna-be, mother fucker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Trevor just stands there, studies Benny. A palpable beat.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Are you done? There is dead silence as Benny stares Trevor straight in the eye. Trevor stares right back.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: gimme a referral. Shit. Jus Trevor turns and calmly walks back to the island counter, searches and finds a referral slip in one of the drawers, fills it out...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (cool deliberation) For future reference, anyone who disrupts a class, or in any way infringes on the rights of others to get an education, is subject to disciplinary action. (beat) When I'm here, ladies and gentlemen, I expect to be treated decently... (walks back to Benny) +. hopefully in an atmosphere of mutual respect. This classroom is our sanctuary, yours and mine. Respect it. (handing Benny the referral) For your information, I am a real teacher.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Opie. Benny has a smirk on his face as he sashays past Trevor with the referral slip.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, who would like to help me pick up the books? Benny, a self-aggrandized exit, crumbles the referral slip and tosses it at Trevor, hitting him square in the back. Like a reflex, Trevor whirls and ducks. Students laugh at his heightened reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see kids at an armored Coke machine. PAN OFF machine to see kids at lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor sits by himself, lost in stirring a bowl of soup. He observes a talkative clique of teachers at the far end of the table, including Teacher #1. Now Dave Childress sits down, disrupting Trevor's solitude.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: How goes the battle, Garfield? Dave bites into a messy sandwich as he skims the front page of a newspaper that someone left behind.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: D'juh get that binky marsden farfied? Trevor doesn't say a word. Just keeps stirring his soup +. Now notices Ellen Henry as she enters and joins the food line.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Know what I think? I think that Chacon punk's the one who opened your bungalow this morning. (another bite) Eskander doesn't know how to lock a window.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN AND CASHIER
dialogues.text: The cashier (Armenian girl, 15) is one of Ellen's students. As Ellen pays for a sandwich...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: .«.. Come by the lab after school, we'll work on it...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Want some advice? Trevor slides Dave a glance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: First homeboy that gives you the slightest bit of trouble... send ‘um tuh Larry Hyland. He's their counselor. Right off the bat, yuh have to sacrifice one. Let ‘um know who's boss. Show some balls. (as Trevor nods) And don't look for support from the administration. Most of ‘em haven't been in a classroom in ten years. They don't know shit. I got tenure and I'm still out here in the damn bungalows. I should be in the 'A' building with a nice air-conditioned room. (sarcastically) You met Garcia yet? The principal? Trevor shakes his head as Ellen Henry takes the empty seat at the end of the table, smiles at Trevor.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Ah! New blood! (extends a hand) Ellen Henry, computer science.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Trevor Garfield. As they shake right in front of Childress' face he can't help noticing the mean scar on the back of Trevor's hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Nice scar yuh got there. There's something familiar about this sub.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Ever sub here before?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: First time.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (curiously) What about permanent?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I taught seven years in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Roosevelt Whitney High School. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Roosevelt Whitney? Didn't some teacher get stabbed to death there last year?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Actually, he survived.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: No, it was on 'Sixty Minutes.' Some gangbanger stabbed this guy with a ten-penny nail like a dozen times in a hallway and... Childress looks from Trevor silently stirring his soup down to the scar again... and now it hits him.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, you're him. It was you. Ellen blanches.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (awestruck) Holy shit, Garfield. When was that? December before last? No, it was fall.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: October 27.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Whadda schmuck. I'm sittin' here givin' advice to a man with a purple heart.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Inexplicably, she gets up and leaves. As Trevor watches Ellen go, Childress slides closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (sotto) Lemme tell yuh somethin’. In my book you're a fuckin' hero. Damn straight. Trevor slides a look back to Dave as he eats his soup.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. Getting stabbed doesn't make me a hero. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (disregards Trevor's comment ) So what'd they give the kid?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: They put ‘im upstate in a facility until his twenty-first birthday.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: That all? They shoulda caned the bastard. Like they did that kid in Singapore. Remember? (recollecting) President of Singapore had a few choice words. Use to have it memorized... He said something like, ‘When a state of increasing disorder and defiance cannot be checked by the rules... then new and sometimes drastic rules have to be forged to maintain order. (slides Trevor a glance) ‘The alternative is to surrender order to chaos and anarchy.'

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: So why do you still teach?

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Same reason as you, Garfield -- for the paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows and blinds are shut now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is inching toward the top of the hour. Closing their books and loading their knapsacks, the students talk and pay more attention to the inexorable projector. march of time than to Trevor writing on an overhead

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, someone tell me the difference between the central nervous system and the lymphatic system? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rita Nartinez (the chola from the "utility" shed) sits near the front of the class. She wears her usual heavy eyeliner and a new nose ring.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (obscenely) Mr. G, you gotta nice butt. Class erupts. Rita enjoys the attention. Trevor turns and looks at her squarely.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You seem to be an expert on anatomy, Miss -- (checks roster) -- Nartinez. Central nervous system and lymphatic system. What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: «+. Uh... Trevor doesn't expect anything remotely close to the right answer.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It's like the central nervous system, that's your brain and spinal cord, and the lymphatic system, that's the stuff in your blood that fights diseases. A beat. Trevor looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Very good. Trevor notices Cesar Sanchez writing on his desk. Stevie cranes his neck to observe. Paco snoozes.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Cesar. Cesar throws back his head and jerks both hands from his desk top. Trevor walks up the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You writing on your desk? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (coolly) You see anything in my hands? (displaying his empty palms) I don't think so. Trevor looks down at the tagging on Cesar's desktop. In one corner are the letters K-O-S, and below that the word "cartoon."

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: K-O-S, what's that? That a tagging crew? Cesar shrugs with a big grin.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Cartoon... Is that you, Cesar? (off no response) 'K-O-S' has something to do with your friend Benny?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: +. Dawg. You're a sucker. K-O-S stands for 'Kappin' Off Suckers.’ Don't disrespect my homeboy, Benny. He don't like it. He don't like you. Trevor dismisses Cesar's comments.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Do me a favor, Cesar. Go get a paper towel from the counter and wipe off your desk. (beat) And Mr. Littleton, please oblige me and turn that tagger shirt inside-out. Stevie wears a fusion T-shirt emblazoned with a giant spray can.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (refusing) Hyland said it was okay, Sucker. Neither of them budge. Momentous deliberation. Now the BELL RINGS and the classroom empties in a matter of seconds. Cesar stares daggers at Trevor as he exits. Rita hangs back, the last one to leave. She doesn't want anyone to see her talking to Trevor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) Don't pay no attention to them. They jus' tryin' tuh fuck wit' you, Mr. G. I mean play wit' you. (beat) Sorry I said you had a nice ass.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (a pensive beat) ... Apology accepted.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (in her own defense) I ain't no school girl.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: God forbid anyone should think that. Rita flickers an awkward smile, turns and exits. The class empties and Trevor is left staring at the empty des where Benny and Cesar sat... WHACK --!Trevor's reverie is broken by a BASKETBALL smashing against the side of the bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: OUT THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: A group of boys grin mischieviously at the reaction they get from Trevor... continue smashing the ball against bungalows.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: shifts his gaze from them to the venetian blinds framing the window... to the clock over his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (AFTER SCHOOL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they open --!revealing the clock --!and just as suddenly close. TILT DOWN to find Trevor working the cords to the blinds he's rigged over the timeplace. A FAINT KNOCK breaks his spell as he glances up to discover Ellen Henry standing in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: May I come in? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yeah... (points at her) ... Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: ELLENA
dialogues.text: (pointing back) Trevor. He sees her looking quizzically at the blinds he's rigged over the clock.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (explaining) I'm making time a reward instead of a distraction. Impressed, Ellen peruses the room now with a benign gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Clever... Listen, I wanted to apologize for jumping up like I did at lunch. I was just feeling a little weird...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: For what it's worth, Dave Childress thinks you walk on water.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Is that a good thing? Ellen flickers a grin, point taken.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I think it takes a lot of courage to go back into a classroom after something like that.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Not if the only thing you ever wanted to do was teach.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Now you see, there's our predicament. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WHACK --!the noise pulls Ellen's attention out the window where the boys play a rough game of BASKETBALL.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I assume you've met Benny Chacon?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (absently) Last week Benny and his tagging crew had Ms. Eskander pinned in the corner over there. (pointing) .-. She's seven months pregnant and he's tormenting her with a broom handle... Can I help you with those? Trevor is trying to put some books on an upper shelf, but he's having trouble raising his arm high enough. Ellen sees he's in pain.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No thanks. She watches him struggle, then breaks the awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So anyway, Gloria kicks Benny... and if the district construes it as assault and battery on a student, she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: They'd do that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: In a heart beat. She's non- tenured, they don't want to get sued... (with resignation) Don't be surprised if she files for stress leave by the end of the week. Too bad, too. She's a good teacher. WHACK... WHACK... Outside, the kids continue to play. The late sun makes their violent shadows swarm over Ellen

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a personal question? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor glances up. Here's what she really wants to know... A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (tentatively now) Why'd that kid attack you?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Because I flunked him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (sobered) Is there any way you can see something like that coming?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: When they say they wanna kill you, you'd best take it serious. This kid was an O.T. --!Opportunity Transfer --!but nobody told me until it was too late.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Did you know Benny's an O.T.?... In less than a year he's been convicted of felony assault and suspended twice. I even testified against him as a character witness. Now I get to see him every day in homeroom. I'm stuck with him. Condition of his probation is that he stay in school.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You talk to the principal?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Many times... Three weeks ago, Garcia calls Benny's mother in for a conference, but she refuses to show up. She's afraid they'll deport her because she's illegal. So she contacts the A.C.L.U. and some attorney tells her she doesn't have to come in. (still can't believe) Garcia got cold feet and dropped the whole thing. (fear building) This kid's threatening me and all he's worried about is a lawsuit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (intent now) What'd Benny say to you? Tears involuntarily well up in Ellen's eyes. HOLD for an awkward moment as she collects herself.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That he wanted to hurt me. Real bad.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Does he know where you live?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I think so. Someone's been phoning me at night and hanging up... Two weeks ago, my car was broken into... And last Friday, I think he was inside my house... But I can't prove it. The shadows of the basketball players rage inside the bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (bottom lip quivers) «+. I don't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You can quit.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You didn't. OFF Trevor's severe gaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Trace the cold underbelly of the overpass. The glare of oncoming headlights flash overhead as we DISCOVER a tagging wall. CLOSER now... .+. The wall is completely covered with graffiti. The centerpiece of the wall is a 5' by 10' multi-color "placa" that reads... K.O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLING TO DISCOVER an Anglo tagger now as he defaces the "S" in K-O-S, covering it with his own piece. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly the lone tagger feels a presence at his back. He freezes. Now slowly turns to see... ... Benny, Cesar and Paco. Merely shadows. Benny lights a blunt, illuminating his face. Passes it to Cesar...

dialogues.speaker: TAGGER
dialogues.text: Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (indicates tagging) You should. You're fuckin' with my piece, puto.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGER
dialogues.text: (nervously) ++. You from K.O.S.? No shit? Cesar and Paco burst into hysterical laughter which only manages to get Benny piqued.

dialogues.speaker: TAGGER
dialogues.text: (panicking) Look, I didn't mean nothin'. Lemme fix it. I can fix it. Okay? Cesar and Paco laugh harder.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (to Cesar) Eh, shut up, mojado! (to Tagger now) Don't mess wit' me, whiteboy. I'11l cap yer ass. He pulls a .380 or a .25 automatic out of his pocket. Brandishes it at Cesar and Paco...

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I said shut up! Shut the fuck up! A BEEPER hooked on Benny's pants pocket BEEPS. Benny shuts it off. The Tagger sees his opportunity and makes a break for it. Without a second thought, Benny SHOOTS him in the leg. Tagger crumbles to the ground. Benny's really pissed now. Checks his beeper's glow-in-the-dark face for the message.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: (reacting to message) I don't have no time to put up wit' ‘dis shit! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cesar and Paco attempt to subdue their laughter but fail...

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You think it's funny?! Benny lifts a pant leg. Indicates his ankle monitor with the barrel of his gun.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: I don't call my P.O. in 15 minutes, I'm fucked. Venting rage, Benny walks up the wounded Tagger and STARTS SHOOTING (one hand high near his face, shooting downward). Now he kisses the crucifix on his rosary like a sick, distorted affectation.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Dis is K.O.S.' neighborhood. Cesar and Paco laugh even harder now, falling all over each other. Benny storms off. He marches past a street lamp and is swallowed up by the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBJECT CAMERA FOLLOWING Benny. Oblivious that he's being followed, Benny walks at a steady pace. As we continue gaining ground on him, a SOUND UPCUT of TREVOR CALLING ROLL transports us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FIRST PERIOD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amid unresponsive cross talk:

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sergio Arrellano... Blanca Orantes... Andrew Blackwell... Benny Chacon...

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIA
dialogues.text: (chiming in) Benny's not here. Trevor gazes opaquely at Benny's empty seat.

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIA
dialogues.text: I think he went AWOL, Mr. G.  42 43 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eight-year-old Hispanic kid pulls a red Flexi-Flyer wagon (laden with pop bottles and aluminum cans) across weeds and cracked earth. He suddenly stops and stares at something in the weeds. Snatches it up, studies it, and tosses it with everything else. SLOWLY MOVING IN ON the wagon now... +. thru a thin shroud of dust as it bangs and bumps along. Even CLOSER now on the last retrieved article... It's Benny's ankle monitor.

dialogues.speaker: DAY, (FIFTH PERIOD)
dialogues.text: Trevor emerges from Assistant Principal Ford's office and walks up the empty corridor, without breaking stride.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muted) ++. Trevor. Trevor retraces his steps back to the door of Ellen's plant-filled, personalized computer lab. Over the CLACKING of COMPUTER KEYS...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (quietly) Eskander filed for stress leave. They want me to finish out the semester.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That's great...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (with humility) It's only 'til the end of the year.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Listen, I never thanked you for letting me cry on your shoulder. Trevor flickers a conciliatory nod, now he averts his eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (digressing now) Hey, have you seen Benny lately? (as Trevor shrugs) Ford told me he hasn't phoned his P.O. in four days. (weighs guilt; whispering) You know what they say. Be careful what you pray for. Don't get me wrong, Benny's made my life a living hell. I even moved back in with my mother because of him. I love my mother, but if I eat one more dinner off a TV tray or watch one more rerun of ‘Wheel of Fortune,' I think I'll lose my fucking mind. Now an EGG TIMER RINGS O.S. on Ellen's desk. Back into the classroom...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (to class) Time's up. Everyone stop working. Realizing now that all the CLACKING COMPUTER KEYS have stopped moments ago. All eyes are fixed on Ellen and Trevor. «+. Big knowing grins all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balmy and still. ON bug zapper above garage, a churning, SLOW MOTION swarm of bugs repeatedly throw themselves headlong into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC plays faintly on the STEREO. Numerous artifacts occupy the bookshelves. A primitive AFRICAN MASAI BOW (with two arrows) is mounted on a wall. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Trevor, tie loosened. Ellen, in nylon stocking feet, leaning back against a couch. On the coffee table before them are dirty dishes and half-full wine glasses. Trevor's lost in a thin introspective smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (breaks the silence) «+. So you have a wife hiding in a closet somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (smile widens) No. No wife.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Don't you ever get lonely? Trevor considers the question.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (genuinely) Sometimes. There's this passage in God's Lonely Man by Thomas Wolfe where he says, '... The whole conviction of my life rests upon the belief that loneliness is the central and inevitable fact of human existence.' I believe that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: God that's depressing. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: +. My New York mentality. (beat) It's not always easy looking on the bright side.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Especially after spending a year in and out of a hospital, I would guess. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Actually, that wasn't the toughest part -- it's the robbery that's been hardest to recover from.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (didn't know about this) What'd they steal? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He offers Rev. 7/10/96 42.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: My passion. My old, unguarded self. I resent that. I want them back. a smile. Ellen returns it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: They're still there. Everybody around me seems to have given up. They're all so beaten down. But you're different. You refuse to be beaten.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: So do you. Kindred souls. Ellen fills her glass.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Remember the last time a student surprised you?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You mean where a light goes on?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Where the kid surpasses all your expectations.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: --. Been awhile. So few you can actually get through to... You?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (thinks ) ... That would have to be Daniel Terrazas. This was last year sometime. Kid was failing miserably .-. But he was the best Salsa dancer in the whole school.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (brightens slightly) Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So I made 'im a deal. Tutoring in exchange for Salsa lessons.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Saw it... Jerry Springer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: No, no. He was a perfect gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (dryly) Male teachers can't do things like that. They get arrested.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yep, double standard... By the way, did you know Cesar Sanchez was Special Ed? (as Trevor shakes his head) Yep, he never should've been mainstreamed. His I.E.P. says he's L.H. but he acts more like S.E.D.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Severely Emotionally Disturbed... that's great. A beat. Then Ellen gets up, wine glass balanced in her left hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Come on, Garfield -- on your feet. Lemme teach you how to Salsa.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (resisting) No, no, I'm no good at that. Ellen spins the tuner on the STEREO to a LATIN STATION and practically yanks Trevor to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Let's go. Don't play shy with me, homeboy. Trevor grimaces, awkwardly relinquishes, as Ellen walks him through it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (still holding wine glass) That's it... Okay, follow me. It starts on the one. Step forward with your left foot... One. Change weight on, two. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And three, feet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: back together... Now do the same in reverse, starting with your right foot. (talks their way through) One, two, three... One, two three... Trevor concentrates. Up to speed now. Technically he's got it, he just needs to loosen up. Ellen suppresses a gleeful snicker. Now, Trevor attempts to cut loose. He spins Ellen once, into a tango step, one-two-three. Now an awkward dip, causing her glass to spill wine down the back of his shirt...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (horrified, giggling) Oh, my God... your shirt. Oh, no, I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) It's alright. He dashes toward the hallway bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Grab the baking soda outta the fridge. In a flurry, Ellen rushes into the kitchen. Flips on the kitchen light, jerks open the refrigerator and locates the baking soda. FOLLOWING now, as she MOVES STEADILY FROM the kitchen TO the hallway bathroom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Ellen steps into the doorway and lets out a startled gasp, dropping the box of baking soda. Trevor is bent over, scrubbing his shirt in the sink. His bare back and shoulders are scattered with brutal knife scars.  49 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tract house in the central San Fernando Valley. Trevor's Rambler is parked at the curb. The house is dark except for a porch light. Trevor and Ellen are greeted by Ellen's golden retriever Jack, who's chained to the front porch. JACK WHIMPERS, ready to bark.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Don't start barking, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (petting him) Hey there, boy. You're a good dog. Yes, you are. Jack nuzzles up to Trevor, tail wagging furiously, no barking. Now Trevor stands and faces Ellen...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Sorry for reacting the way I did back there.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Don't apologize. That's how most people react.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Didn't scare me. It just surprised me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: --. Thanks for dinner. I had a good time.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Awkward silence. Trevor struggles with the urge to kiss her good night. They look at each other timidly for a moment. Now he moves to kiss her and she inadvertently adjusts her stance. The result is a kiss that doesn't quite hit her mouth. It's an awkward moment. Ellen feels horrible for him, desperately picks up a strange little plant by her feet.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Here... you need a little life in that place of yours. Trevor takes it, smiles "thanks"...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «++ Good night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -.+. turns and starts toward his car...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (a half-wave) «+. Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the moonlit darkness. Trevor's abandoned bed. The sheets are twisted and damp. We TILT UP to see a digital clock at bedside reading 2:49 AM, and Trevor's sweat- panted figure moving down the hall in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: madly pedaling TOWARD us on a bike. He wears running shoes, shorts and a Morehouse College sweat shirt and his face is contorted from the effort. He wipes sweat from his head, takes a gasping hit from his inhaler as CAMERA CRANES UP to reveal Trevor on a stationary bike in the back yard of his house, rapidly going nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sleepless night continues. Planted at his desk. Trevor corrects a stack of science papers, like a fervent prayer. Sun peeks through the window above his desk.

dialogues.speaker: OVER SUBURBAN CLUTTER
dialogues.text: Then burning out to white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimmering in heat waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sweltering. A single fan stirs the air. Amidst growing disorder, Trevor stands behind the front counter. AGENDA is written on the overhead as he flips through pages of a physical science text book. Rita's out of her seat, feeding the caged, white lab rat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cesar, with sunglasses and typical disregard, holds court in the back of the room. He and Stevie are high. Trevor eyes them, finds what he was looking for in the book...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (addressing class) Since some of you seem to have an interest in anesthetics, I've prepared a little demonstration. Glances over at Rita now. Checks the wall clock.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Rita, bring your friend in the cage over here, please. Bringing the cage over...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: His name's Snowball. Like ‘dat 1il' pig dude from Animal Farm.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (coolly impressed) You've read Animal Farm?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (above the din) «+. schoolgirl.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (snapping a look) Shut up, Cesar.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You read Animal Farm, Cesar?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: No, but I fucked a sheep. Stevie and Paco love it.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Cesar, come up here. (gesturing) I want you to have a front row seat for this. Surprisingly, Cesar does what he's told as Trevor removes an old pocket watch from his briefcase and sets it next to Snowball's cage... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: And remove the 'lokes.' Cesar removes his dark glasses. His eyes are bloodshot and vapid.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Why your eyes so red?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (lying) ; Mus' be pink-eye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (eyes Trevor's pocket watch) Nice watch, homes. Can I have it? Disregarding Cesar, Trevor opens a drawer and removes two latex surgical gloves from a cardboard box. He puts on the gloves and selects a petri dish from another drawer.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pointing) Rita, would you bring me a sugar cube from the shelf over there? She does. Trevor now removes a small amber bottle (with an eye-dropper top) from his briefcase. The class starts to settle down now as Trevor pre-measures water in a pipette and adds it to the petri dish.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (veferring to text) Cesar, read Young's rule for us. Page 564. At the top.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (like it's above him) I ain't gonna read ‘dat shit.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Rita, give Cesar your book. Let ‘im read. Rita places her book on Cesar's desk.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Forget it. Jeers from the class, "Come on, read". "Hurry up, Cesar." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (prompting him) ‘Young's rule...' Go on. Rita points to the passage in the book. Cesar slaps her hand.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (reacting) --. Chunt. (Choont.)

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Stoopit bitch.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Touch her again, Cesar, and you'll answer to me personally. Rita knits her eyebrows at Trevor. Cesar laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: You like her, Mr. G? Class erupts.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (shrinking) Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (genuinely) Settle down, everyone. We all have to learn how to forgive and get along. C'mon, Cesar, read. Please. At first Cesar doesn't budge. Now grudgingly he looks down at the book...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (attempting to read) .»». Young's rule... ff... fo...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... Formulates. Cesar heaves the book across the room: Class erupts, "Refer ‘im," "Send 'im tuh Hyland." Trevor walks over and picks up the book. Class now settles. Watches Trevor closely to see what he's going to do. Trevor gazes at Cesar... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... I say everyone deserves another chance. Whadda you say, Cesar? Cesar knits his eyebrows, puzzled. Now Trevor walks over and sets the textbook down in front of Rita...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Rita, would you please read Young's rule for me?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (hesitates and...) .-. ‘Young's rule formulates proper dosage levels for children and adolescents.'

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Thank you. Resume the lesson now. Trevor indicates the amber bottle.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-. In the brown bottle I have a prescription for liquid Demeral.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Where'd that come from, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: A doctor. Cesar grudgingly watches as Trevor places a measured drop of the liquid demeral into the petri dish and stirs the solution.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Demeral is a morphine sulphate... and is soluble in water. Using the pipette, Trevor administers two drops of the demeral and water solution to the sugar cube, which he has placed inside Snowball's cage. As Snowball eats the sugar cube...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Young's rule says, divide the age of the patient by the patient's age plus twelve, giving us the fraction of the adult dosage suitable for the patient. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In Snowball's case, I've calculated the dosage necessary to tranquilize a one-year-old child... then further divided that fraction by 30, based on his weight, to arrive at .002 milligrams. Having eaten most of the sugar cube, Snowball is rendered unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: +. Don't worry, he'll be back to normal in exactly 10 minutes. Trevor peers at his pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: FULL SCREEN
dialogues.text: The hour and minute hands read 2:40. HOLD as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor's pocket watch now reads 2:50...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: ... He shoulda woke up by now? Snowball isn't moving. HOLD for an uncomfortably long moment ON the class, clustered around Trevor's desk. The class, for once, is completely silent. Beads of perspiration form on Trevor's upper lip as he resolutely watches the sleeping rat.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (accusatory) You just caught a murder case, homes. Now Snowball begins to stir and the class reacts with scattered applause. A thin smile flickers across Trevor's face. As the BELL RINGS....

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, anyone who didn't finish answering the questions on 246, finish them for homework. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As students head for the doors, he pulls off his latex gloves and looks for his pocket watch... but it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Hold it, Cesar. Cesar and Stevie are almost out the door.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Where's my watch?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (urgently) Hey, I gotta go. I ain't got no watch.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Empty your pockets, both of you.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Want me to break it down to you? I gotta catch a bus. Cesar heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor locks bungalow #86, picks up his briefcase, and along with the rest of the foot traffic, heads in the direction of the "A" building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trevor rounds a corner and runs smack into Ellen on the opposite side of a chain link fence.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (making excuses) Sorry. I'm trying to catch Hyland before he leaves. Trevor keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I've been meaning to come by your room.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (keeping it light) .-+. It's almost been a week. My guess is you're avoiding me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Trevor's tongue-tied. Now he removes the Proventil inhaler from his pocket, take an innocuous hit.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You okay? Trevor nods, sustains an awkward smile.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Has nothing to do with you, Ellen. It's... hard for me... A struggle, fighting against his true feelings...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Pretty much been like that since... you know, my accident. Has nothing to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Is it because I'm white?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No. Trevor stares into her eyes, a soulful, searching gaze. Now he averts a self-conscious look.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We can still be friends. Just don't pull away. Trevor just looks at her. Nods, somewhat bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (back to lighter note) Now, can I ask you a favor? After you're done with Hyland, can you give me a ride to my car? It's at the mechanics, about five or six blocks up Lankershim. If you can't, it's okay, I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) +. I think I can manage that. Victor Sifuentes approaches now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Que paso, Victor? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (into walkie-talkie) Base three to base one. ‘Found ‘im. As their paths converge and they stop, face to face...

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Garcia would like to speak with you in his office. OFF Trevor's puzzled look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall air conditioner... blows on Stevie and Cesar's sweaty backs. Trevor enters, shirt equally drenched in sweat. The dead silence is like that of a courtroom. MR. GARCIA, late forties, drawn, sits behind his desk... MR. HYLAND, stands in the outer office behind a glass partition, head lowered. Hyland flashes Trevor a defeated smile as we... Trevor coolly deciphers the situation. Garcia reaches down, switches on a portable tape recorder

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: You don't mind if I tape record our conversation. Matter of record. You understand. (indicating Mr. Hyland) Of course, you know Mr. Hyland. Trevor weighs the situation. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Am I being questioned?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: (beat) Mr. Sanchez and Mr. Littleton tell me you've accused them of stealing your watch. If that's the case, I need to address the accusation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-. For the record, I primarily suspect Mr. Sanchez. Although I wouldn't be surprised if Stevie was an accomplice. (glances over at Cesar and Stevie) Beginning of sixth period, Cesar admired the watch. I believe his exact words were, 'Can I have it? (looks back to Garcia) Either way, I'd like my watch back.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: When I asked him to empty his pockets, Cesar refused.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Is that true, Mr. Sanchez?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: No way. He never asked me nothin' like that! I don't go ‘round taxing no teachers...

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Okay. Calm down. With fervor now, Cesar turns his pockets inside out, emptying the contents (house keys and two dollars in change) onto Garcia's desk. Stevie dollar Trevor Garcia

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: -+. I ain't got no watch, man.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Mr. Littleton, may we see your pockets too? empties his pockets now. Nothing but a twenty bill and an empty pack of Marlboros. just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (last try) I'd like a locker search, please. hesitates, now looks to Cesar and Stevie... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: You're excused, gentlemen. Take your things. Thank you. The boys collect their belongings off Garcia's desk and shoot looks at Trevor as they exit. Now Garcia turns back to Trevor...

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: (unflinching pragmatism) .-. Let me try and explain something. I try and think of our students here at John Quincy Adams like they're my clients. I can't accuse anybody just on your hunches. I need more than that. I need facts. (looking at Hyland) I won't have another law suit like we did with that Blackwell case. (now to Trevor) Boy's mother spent $400 that she couldn't afford on new clothes for her son. Unfortunately we considered the clothing gang attire and sent the boy home. That cost the district a quarter of a million dollars. (beat) So I want you to be straight with me, Mr. Garfield. Did you physically see Cesar take your watch?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No, I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Do you have any witnesses who saw him take it?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pause) «+. No.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Unless there's reasonable cause to show that Cesar, or Mr. Littleton took your watch then I can't authorize a locker search. I'm sorry. Any concerns regarding my decision, you can look up in the handbook. It's section 628.1 of the Education Code. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (to Garcia) That was my grandfather's watch. Can't you see what they're doing? Weren't you ever a teacher?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Afraid I never had the privilege. Teaching and being a principal don't necessarily go hand in hand, Mr. Garfield. OFF Trevor's defeated gaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trevor and Hyland emerge from Garcia's office and walk steadily up the empty corridor...

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: (sotto) Is it me or is Garcia a real asshole? Trevor doesn't respond, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about videotaping my classes.

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: .-. Yeah, well, here's some free advice. Cover your ass. Trevor slides him a glance. They stop in front of Hyland's office door. He unlocks the door with a key...

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: If Garcia asks, your main purpose is to observe you, not the students. Excuse me, I mean his ~clients.' PHONE RINGS as they enter...

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: Some gangbanger might think we're violating his civil rights... Trevor weighs it as Hyland picks up the phone... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: (into phone) ++. Yeah? Signals Trevor to take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sorry, Iris. Completely forgot. INTERCUT Trevor as his eyes idly fix on an index card box (on Hyland's desk) labeled, "LOCKER COMBINATIONS." Hyland hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
