dialogues.text: (to Trevor) Yuh have a minute? Wanna talk to you about our discipline committee. Gotta run up to the office real quick first. Trevor shifts his gaze back to Hyland.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine, go ahead. I'1l wait. Hyland rushes out and Trevor glances back at the index box. Momentous deliberation. Now he reaches over and carefully opens the small tin box. Methodically now, he flips through the file cards until he finds Cesar Sanchez's locker combination. Trevor's eyes scanning the information on the locker combination card. LOCKER #204. Combination sequence...08-24-53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor's Rambler, with Ellen in the passenger seat, stops at a large intersection.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: ... I have to fly up there for a computer conference.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: When's that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Day after tomorrow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Trevor gets distracted by something he sees...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Never been to San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a right angle to Lankershim, down Magnolia Blvd., Rita Nartinez sits alone on a bus stop bench.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, you should go sometime, Trevor. I think you'd like it. Really. It's only an hour by air. Maybe five or six by car. Completely different attitude from L.A. Much more like a real city... like Chicago or New York... As Ellen continues talking we see a lowered blue Nissan mini-truck (with matching shell) pull up next to the bus stop. A cholo from the utility shed hangs out the passenger window and taunts Rita. Rita immediately stands and walks back down Magnolia. The mini-truck follows her in reverse. Rita halts and begins ranting at the cholo, waving her arms all around. Now she stomps away and the mini-truck drives away with a lurch.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «+. Only problem is I hate to leave Jack with my mother for any extended period of time. I'm afraid she'll forget to feed him and he'll starve to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT Trevor's distracted gaze.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: If you want, I'll take care of Jack.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I can't ask you to do that.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (straight at Ellen now) Sure you can.  66 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor's conference period. He stands atop a ladder in the front of the room, drilling holes in the wall for a jerry-rigged camera mount. As he climbs down, Rita enters. Paces back and forth, wringing a clenched spiral notebook, English Comp. essay tucked inside...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (continues working) ... Aren't you supposed to be at P.E. fifth period?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (rants; kicks a desk) --. Sunland Boyz gettin' crazy, ol lady's... fucked up. Fuck dis being down shit. I wanna do somethin' wit' my life. A POLAROID PHOTO drops out of her notebook. Trevor reaches down and scoops it up.

dialogues.speaker: POLAROID PHOTO/DEAD GANG MEMBER IN CASKET
dialogues.text: Puppet... a young 16-year-old cholo, dressed in gang colors, laid out in an open casket.

dialogues.speaker: ON TREVOR
dialogues.text: Now as he hands the photo back to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .»+. You know this guy? Rita takes the photo back. She doesn't want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (unravels now; begins to cry) ‘Gotta make J-C next year. 'Got to! I ain't never gonna get up outta here.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Rita, slow down.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: ‘Dat bitch Quinn, I'm 'onna sue her ass. ‘Swear tuh God...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Calm down a second. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rita collapses into a desk.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Who's Quinn? What's she teach?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: English Comp. She's failin' me. Trevor tentatively picks up Rita's essay (branded with a big red "F") and begins reading it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: ‘Bitch say I don't talk right. Trevor scrutinizes her with a glance. Now back to Rita's essay.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: She hates me. She's racist against me. Trevor sets the essay down on Rita's desk. Regards her with genuine candor...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Just cause you're a Latina doesn't mean everyone's racist against you.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (prideful) Hey, I'm a La Raza, prof-eh.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Okay... just stop blaming everyone else. You're too smart for that. (as Rita's rocked back) And every mistake in that essay is fixable, okay? So relax, it's not the end of the world. Rita collects herself, wipes the streaks of mascara running down her cheeks with her sleeve. Trevor studies her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (points to counter) Tissues are in the first drawer. Rita pulls herself together and walks over to the island counter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (innocuously) How come you always wear so much makeup?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (wounded) ... To make me pretty.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (frankly) You don't need it. She grabs a handful of tissues, dabs at her smeared mascara. Now her hair falls forward, exposing the back of her neck... and a tattoo that reads "Puppet" in a scrawling signature. She tosses her hair back and it disappears.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (slightest bit probative) That your name? He indicates the back of her neck.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (with fervor and frustration) It's a gang thing. But I'm kickin' dat shit... Jus' cuz I look down for my neighborhood don't mean I'm stupit.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I know you're not. She inserts her "failed" essay inside the rolled-up spiral notebook.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (offers) The ideas in your essay aren't the problem, Rita. It's your punctuation and grammar. (beat) They need work. Am I lying? (as Rita shrugs) If you want help I'm here for you. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (tentatively now) .-. I dunno. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Have to be in the library after school.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) .+. Somebody could see us.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: All right then, I'll come to your house.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (spontaneous and decisive) No... No way.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Where then? You name the place. The passing BELL for 6th period RINGS. OFF Rita's torn gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (6TH PERIOD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-. fully mounted now on the wall above the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every eye in the class is riveted on the camera. SETTLE ON Cesar and Stevie seated in the back of the bungalow. OFF their malignant stares...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (grumbling) Dog, you invadin' my privacy. Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (remaining calm) Cesar, would you come up here please? Leveling a hard look, Cesar swaggers up to the island counter. Rita watches, a bated gaze, from her seat. Trevor motions for him to come around behind the counter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now Trevor removes his grandfather's pocket watch from his briefcase and furtively dangles it for Cesar to see.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (calmly) Since you were so concerned, I though you might like to know... I found my watch. Cesar glares at the watch, looks up at the video camera.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: «+.» You broke into my locker. Dat's a serious felony, prof-eh. You caught a case for sure now.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Whadda yuh propose to do, Cesar? Tell Garcia? (as Cesar weighs it) Whadda yuh gonna tell ‘im? That I broke into your locker to steal back the watch you denied taking? I don't think so. I'd say we're even now, wouldn't you, Cesar?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: No, I'd say we're just getting started, ese. Cesar walks out. Trevor smiles innocuously. Ata stalemate now. You can hear a pin drop. Suddenly the CRIES of an E.N.A.B.L. BABY break the palpable tension...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. Trevor's Rambler is parked out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stilted Rita, planted on the couch. Wearing less makeup than usual. Her notebook and pens are laid out on the coffee table along with an old English grammar textbook. Trevor stands in the kitchen doorway... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Want something to drink? We have Coke, Fanta or Sprite...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (self-consciously) «+. Coke's awright. OFF Trevor's mollifying nod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of self-examination as he pours a glass of Coke for Rita...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (to Rita offstage) ‘Want you to know, you're not the only one risking a reputation here. Normally I don't tutor students at my house. (adds ice cubes) Rita, maybe you can clear something up. Can you explain to me what machismo is all about? Cuz this whole respect/code of honor thing baffles me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Trevor approaches the couch, eyes focused on Rita's soda.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Ask yourself this question. Is pride really that important? Now he looks up and freezes. Quickly turns away. Rita, lying on the couch, completely naked. Not sexual in the least. More like a distorted offering. Or a patient, placidly waiting for her doctor.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (plainly) Put your clothes on, Rita. An awkward moment. Chagrin becomes repressed sobs as Rita picks up her pile of clothes off the floor and gets dressed. This is one fucked-up little girl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (affected) No harm done... Don't cry now. Fully dressed again, remotely staring, Rita holds back tears. Trevor sits down on the couch next to her. Opens textbook.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Why don't you go ahead and copy the first rule there for the verb ‘to be.' Can you do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (hiccups a sob) I jus' wan'ed to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You don't have to thank me, I'm your teacher. Rita opens her notebook and begins to copy the rule. She wipes at the tears with the sleeve of her baggy sweat shirt. Trevor resists the urge to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... From now on I think the best thing for us to do is meet in the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor kneels at the foot of his bed. Fully dressed, shirt and loosened tie. Glimpses up at the crucifix on the wall. Bows his head again...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (prayerfully, to himself «e. I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOMING DOWN FROM the Blythe St. sign... A cement barricade covered in graffiti chokes off street traffic. ... Crack dealers and gangbangers freely wander the rows of clapboard tenements, kids throwing sneakers, bangers drinking from glass bottles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now apartment 105 (Cesar Sanchez's). MOVING IN ON the MUTED sounds of an ARGUMENT (in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dingy. Yellowing walls. Cesar and his mother continue their arguing as Cesar watches first the "Animaniacs" and switches channels to "The Deer Hunter," while his BABY SISTER CRIES in her high chair. MRS. SANCHEZ is older looking than her thirty-four years. Clutching her purse...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: (on the verge (subtitles... You stay of tears) out of my ..- Deja mis cosas, Cesar. things, Cesar. You hear Me oyes? Ese dinero es me? That money puts para poner comida en el plato de tu hermanita. food on your baby sister's plate. Cesar yells at his SISTER to stop CRYING... CESAR (subtitlesshut up, Callate el osico, Rosillo! Rosillo! (now to his mother) Que? Me estas mandando? You tellin' me what to Yo soy el hombre de esta do?! I'm the man in casa! Enceneme respeto! this house! you show me respect!) MRS. SANCHEZ (subtitlesIf£f you're the Pues si eres tan hombre, ve busca trabajo. Para que mantengas a tu madre y hermanita y no tenga que robar de mi bolsa. man then go get a job. Take care of your mother and sister. Don't rob from my purse.) In a rage, Cesar digs into his pocket and throws twenty dollars in his mother's face. She cowers. CESAR (subtitlesHere, I don't Tenga, no nesecito su need your pinche, apestoso dinero! stinkin' money!) They're interrupted by a KNOCK at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (indicating door) I ain't getting it. You get it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cesar plops down on an old worn out recliner and goes back to watching "Animaniacs" on the TELEVISION. ROSILLO STOPS her CRYING and Mrs. Sanchez carefully gathers the money scattered at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the screen door, a silhouette fills the doorway. MOVING IN ON CESAR. He can faintly hear the 0.S. conversation as he watches TV.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: (O.S.) (subtitlesYes, who's Si, quien es? there?) TREVOR (0.S.) (subtitlesMrs. Sanchez? Senora Sanchez? Soy el I'm Mr. senor Garfield, Profesor Garfield, Cesar's de ciencia de Cesar. science teacher.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SANCHEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (surprised) Si, maestro. Cesar's stunned look lifts him from the recliner. TREVOR (0.S.) (subtitlesI know it's Se que es tarde. Ojala no late. Hope este estorbando nada. I'm not disturbing Me permite hablar con anything. May I speak usted por un momento? with you a moment?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SANCHEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Entre, por favor.

dialogues.speaker: SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: PIVOTING now to see Trevor enter the front door. Cesar glares with flint-hard eyes at Trevor.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Hello, Cesar. Breaking his unrelenting stare, Cesar now squeezes past Trevor and out the screen door, slamming it behind him.  77 78 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Sanchez cradles Rosillo in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: (beside herself) (subtitlesI don't know No se que hacer, maestro. what to El no hace caso. do, maestro. He doesn't listen to me.) ROSILLO begins to CRY again... MRS. SANCHEZ (subtitlesGod, but there Perdona me Dios, pero hay are veces que quisiera times I want to kill matarlo. him. ) Suppressing her emotions, she comforts her baby. Trevor weighs a vacuous stare. Now he notices a bruise under Mrs Sanchez's hairline, above her left eye.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (indicating bruise) (subtitlesHow'd that Como paso eso? Arriba del happen... ojo? above your eye?) Overcome with shame, she attempts to cover the bruise.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Nada... es nada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steadfast and unflinching, Trevor beats a path back to his car, parked outside the barricade. Cesar now appears from nowhere. Carries a '40 ouncer' in a paper bag. He's been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (venting rage) Puto! You lied to Benny. You said you don't speak no Spanish!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: ‘At's bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Enjoy hitting your mother, Cesar? You must be proud of yourself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A handful of gangbangers, drinking and loitering around Trevor's car, sharpen their stares and listen intently. Cesar grows nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (to gangbangers) .-. He's lyin', man. (at Trevor) Fuckin' liar! Homeboy don't never disrespec' his mother. Never. You hear me, joto?!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Cesar. Trevor steps around the gangbangers and climbs into his car...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: I'll find out where you stay. Trucha, homes! As the Rambler drives away Cesar heaves his 40 ouncer at it. Shatters all over the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Valla ala chingada! Cesar stands in the middle of the street, throwing hand signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor approaches, via the parking lot, through a gate in a chain-link fence. ADJUST the ANGLE now to discover first period students mobbing the open doorway of Bungalow #86.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pushing through) ‘Scuse me. What's going on? (and) Lakesia, who opened the door?

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIA
dialogues.text: It was like that when I got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor squeezes through the doorway to find Dave Childres pacing the bungalow, assessing the damage. VIDEO CAMERA (AND HOUSING) are scattered in pieces all over the floor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: One of the windows is smashed-in. A serpentine trail of BLACK SPRAY PAINT encircles the entire room. Provocative epithets tag the walls... "Pinche madre", "Puto" and "Fuc you G!"

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Whoever did this is gonna pay! Better believe it, ese(s). A curious stream of students fill the room now. Childress vents his anger at them...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (crazed now) Get the hell outta here!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Dave... (to Armenian kid) Barsek, don't touch anything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Get out!! And now Snowball... as Barsek discovers him... Lifeless. Impaled by a pair of scissors on the front counter.

dialogues.speaker: BARSEK
dialogues.text: (an incredulous, sickened laugh) Oh, damn. lLookit the rat. OFF Trevor's stricken gaze... Childress snaps. He grabs Barsek by the throat. The crowd scatters, students tripping over each other to get out of the bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Think it's funny?! Huh?! Yuh little fuck! Trevor attempts to separate Childress from Barsek...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Dave! No! Let go of ‘im!

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (to Barsek) D'you do this?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARSEK
dialogues.text: (choking) Nooo... Trevor pries them apart. Barsek crumbles to the floor, gulping for air and scurrying out of the bungalow on his hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: He didn't do anything. He's a good kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING the different student factions. MUSIC, playing over a PUBLIC ADDRESS SYSTEM, fills the quad. Trevor, now an interloper, crossing the senior lawn, openly searching for Cesar. Tag-bangers, a clique of eight or nine K.O.S. wanna-be(s) Feature PACO (16) as they take quick hits off a blunt. Now Cesar extinguishes the blunt with his fingertips and hides it as Trevor wanders into their midst.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (glances around; sniffs) Been smokin' the chronic, Cesar?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (a smirk) I'm hooked on phonics... not ‘hooked on chronic.’ Laughs all around.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (not amused) You wouldn't happen t'know who vandalized bungalow eighty-six last night?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (feigning ignorance) You guys know anything about that? (off silence) Sorry, maestro... nada. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (sotto) Garcia may not think there's enough here to prove anything. But you and I both know who's responsible. Don't we?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Whadda you, a narc? Seriously, I don't know what the fuck you're talkin' about. Trevor maintains his fervent demeanor. Now he notices the ring on Cesar's right index finger.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR'S RING
dialogues.text: emblazoned with a green marijuana leaf.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pointing) The ring, Cesar... lemme have it. Cesar dramatically jerks back his finger.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Watch it, eh... that's my trigger finger. As Cesar, with purpose, aims an invisible gun at Trevor.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: It's inappropriate attire...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: -.. Bang.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (momentous deliberation) «+. Are you finished? Cesar starts to laugh. A crowd begins to gather.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: What? Finished with what? Don't get crazy on me, dude. The boisterous crowd escalates... hoots and hollers. After weighing the situation, Trevor exchanges palpable looks with Cesar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now he reluctantly back-pedals, squeezing his way past the wall of bodies pressed in behind him. His departure across an empty lawn is accompanied by a hail of "boos" and taunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as an 737 ROARS down onto the tarmac. In the f.g., Trevor and Ellen PEEL away from the curb angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traveling down Hollywood Way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the front seat...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: «+. These conferences mainly focus on software now.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (far off) Software sells.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (flickers a smile) So, how's Jack?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. Jack's good. As they pull up to a stop light...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (flirtatious) And what about Trevor? Was Trevor a good boy, too? Triggers an unintended response...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (self-consciously) What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (innocently) Nothing... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Is that supposed to mean something?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (baffled) Trevor... The light changes to green. An impatient young man in the car behind them BEEPS his HORN. Lays it on a little too long. Trevor snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trevor gets out of the car, marching up to the car behind, slamming his hand down on its hood...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Can't you see I'm talking to the lady?! The young man shrinks, quickly rolling up his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Trevor gets back in and they drive away. Not a word is spoken. Exorcising his demons now. He simmers.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-. I'm sorry. Forgive me. OFF Ellen's disturbed gaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Rambler pulls into the driveway. Ellen's '92 Jeep Cherokee is parked on the street. Bug zapper above the garage flickers on.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Light now spills into the front yard. No sign of Jack. Trevor SHUTS OFF the IGNITION. A portentous silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: +--+ Come out, come out, wherever you are. Where is he? Trevor reaches for a flashlight in the glove compartment.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: Trevor and Ellen step out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ‘ (tentatively) Jack? MOVING THROUGH the chain-link fence, into the front yard. Ellen whistles faintly. Trevor turns on his flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Here, boy... here, Jack. Come to Mommy, sweetheart. The glare of the flashlight fixes on the trunk of the olive tree. Jack's chain stretching tautly toward the back alley.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (reacting) «+. Oh, my God. Trevor and Ellen, propelled now toward the alley, hearts pounding, frantically rushing toward the conclusion as the flashlight traces the length of the chain...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (cight behind Trevor) Jack?! The chain disappears over the top of the alley wall. Trevor kicks open the alley gate and freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: centered in the flashlight beam, dangling there, strangled to death at the end of his dog collar.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (gut-wrenching) Jack! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Trevor holds her back. She unleashes her torment, punchin and kicking until fully spent, crumbling to her knees now sobbing hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: «+. Jack. HOLD ON her fitful sobs, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (APPROXIMATELY AN HOUR LATER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor, a beaten hypnotic gaze, watches as an ANIMAL REGULATIONS OFFICER fatefully slams the cargo door of his

dialogues.speaker: ANIMAL REGULATIONS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Don't beat yourself up too much. It was an accident. He was probably after a cat... or someone walked past back here in the alley. Whatever it was, he jumped over the fence. What can you do? Ellen watches Trevor's house; behind a screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen sits on Trevor's bed, fighting back tears. Trevor enters with a glass of water and a pill. Sits down on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (offering pill) It's aspirin...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (vefuses it) .»+. I can't talk to you right now, Trevor. Please. I'm so upset I can't even drive. I just need some time alone. Trevor acquiesces. Steps over to his desk and sets the glass of water down. A key protrudes from one of the desk drawers. He leans over, removes the key and plays with it for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (beat) I know about what's not fair. I left part of my lung in a damn hospital because some gangbanger didn't like the grade I gave him. Sometimes you do all the right things. You work hard in school... get a good job... pay your taxes. Things still go bad. (eyes flicker) I'm so sorry, Ellen. Ellen shuts her heavy eyelids now. Shuts out the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thorough investigation now at the foot of Jack's wall... .+. Trevor's flashlight fixes on a faint set of shoe prin in the dirt. Waffle-soled Doc Martens. He follows their trail, down the alley. Hesitating at the wall again. He now focuses his flashlight beam on a smattering of graffiti... and discovers a fresh tag... In black spray paint, the letters K.O.S. Trevor reaches out and touches a coagulated trickle of paint. As he inspects the faint residue on his fingertip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 2 a.m. The street's empty. Cesar's darkened apartment is tucked away in the distance. Now a lone figure emerges and beats a path through the projects... CLOSER now... it's Cesar. White T-shirt, sagging gray dickies... FOLLOWING HIM now... as he crosses the edge of a dirt lot. FOCUSING ON his Doc Marten boots and their waffle- soled print...  97 98 99 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merging with Cesar as he slinks down the dark alley corridor. Lighting a blunt off his Zippo lighter...

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER DOWN 98
dialogues.text: Cesar spray paints a wall with a can of black enamel pain He takes another hit. Chokes down a shit-eating grin. And admires his work... a goofy dog smoking a blunt. +. below the dog he scrawls the word, "CARTOON." Above it, "K.O.S. As he slips the spray can into his front pocket, he senses a presence...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: «+. ‘At you, Stevie? Profound silence. Grin dissolves. Riveted, Cesar takes another slow hit off his blunt. Suddenly a coyote darts past him.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (startled) .-. Hells, man. Stupit dog. His sick smirk returns. But only momentarily. Nowa premonitory flicker registers on his face. He blinks as a Masai arrow splits the darkness and pierces his left pectoral muscle. Exhaling a stunned breath, Cesar looks down at the arrow. An incredulous, stupefied laugh escapes him as he pulls the arrow out of his chest and studies it... The normal length of the arrow's been shortened by half and the tip has been fitted with a modified hypodermic needle. (The needle extends from a rubber stopper which h retracted into the hypodermic casing, causing the solution in the hypo to jettison through the needle and into Cesar).

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: ++. Mutha fuck. Now back-pedaling, stumbling, dropping the arrow, he turns and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cesar collapses onto a pile of garbage bags. MOVING IN. His eyes fixed and dilated. Forehead beaded with perspiration. Fighting against the effects of the injection... Now blackness...  100 101 102 103 104 105 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/10/96 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen awakens with a start. She glances about, momentarily disoriented. Now she remembers where she is and what happened.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Trevor? No response. Choking back emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV SET ON. Ellen enters, glances around. No Trevor.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Trevor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ellen returns. She notices the glass of water on the desk. Bravely collects herself. Crosses over to the desk and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: «+. Where'd you put the aspirin? Like an involuntary reflex she tugs on the center drawer of the desk, but it's locked. Now she pulls on one of the side drawers and it slides open. Ellen stops at what she sees... «+. a treasure-trove of homemade shivs, Bic lighters, Walkmen, pagers... and Benny Chacon's black rosary beads. BACK TO Ellen and her curious, sobered look. Now she slow shuts the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fumbling in her purse for her keys, Ellen makes a hasty departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost six AM. Encroaching sunlight creeps toward the horizon. A vapid stillness. Not a soul stirs.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: as he comes to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eyes feverish, registering pain. His head throbs. He begins to move and discovers a pounding in his right hand... .-. Lifting his hand up in front of his face. Cesar's ring index finger has been severed clean off. Blood is everywhere. Cesar emotes a silent panic-stricken scream. Reduced to a snot-sobbing wreck, he frantically searches the ground on his hands and knees...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: My finger. Please, somebody help me! Where's my finger?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSHING IN ON the Emergency Room Sign... MOVING PAST the unrelenting urgency that permeates the ER. DISCOVER Cesar now in a wheelchair, right hand completely wrapped in gauze. He pleads with two police DETECTIVES...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: +. I put it on my mother, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (leaning forward; good cop) -.. So your science teacher shot you with an arrow full of drugs then chopped off your finger. Come on, you can do better than that, Cesar.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: It had to be him!

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (bad cop) He smoke the ~“mota' for yuh, too, eh ese?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Pinche madre... he hates my guts, man!

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: You covering for somebody, homes? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Cuz, this circumstantial bullshit won't hold up in court, I'll tell you that right now. Detective #1 refers to a rap sheet...

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (sadly) Caught too many priors, Cesar. Juvenile GTA, vandalism...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: I know he did it! Don't you hear what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: You saw his face?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (lying) . Yeah, yeah. I seen him. Detective #2 shakes his head and grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Lemme save yuh from perjuring yourself, asshole... You're full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: I swear it! For reals!

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: (turns to leave) C'mon, this guy's wasting our time. (points to Cesar) Come up with something better than that, or the truth, then maybe we'll talk. Detective #2 walks away. Detective #1 follows. Cesar hangs his head, mumbling a disparaging flood of Spanish expletives...

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: THROUGH passing patients and personnel... APPROACHING the receiving desk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ... As the blurred shoulder of an orderly CROSSES OUT to reveal a legal-sized white envelope now on the counter top. A busy E.R. nurse notices the envelope. Glances around. Picks up the envelope and reads the name typed across the face of it... CESAR SANCHEZ... narrowing her gaze as she opens the envelope. In the envelope, Cesar's severed finger, nesting in a clump of newspaper. Appears to be something tattooed across the side of it but we can't quite make it out. The Nurse gasps and drops the envelope, spilling the finger onto the counter top. CLOSE now ON the finger and the fresh "tatt" scrawled across its side: R-U-DUN? SOUND FADES now from the scene, replaced by a TECHNO HIP- HOP TRACK that CONTINUES THROUGH the CUT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain lashes the faculty parking lot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIP-HOP TRACK FADES now replaced by the buzz of cross-talk. Trevor strolls the aisles, an open science book in hand. (NOTE: Rita is dressed in overalls, very subdued compared to her usual attire.) Cesar's back... and seated in his regular seat, across from Stevie Littleton. Uncharacteristically, his eyes are fixed on the book in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (addressing class) .-. Name one of four parts that make up the human hand? Trevor holds up his hand for display.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... Hands, please. A reluctant cross section of hands go up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 6th period is by no means a synchronized whole but there has developed an odd sort of order to its madness. Trevor looks around. Picks on an Anglo girl in the second row.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Christian.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: ... The metacarpals.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: The Metacarpals. That's one. (to class) Name some more? Now he picks on Rita...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: The wrist... and thumb. A flurry of thumbs go up as if on cue.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Good. (holding up all his fingers now) +. And don't forget the phalanges. Fingers shoot up and wiggle on cue...

dialogues.speaker: CLASS
dialogues.text: (in unison) Phalanges, phalanges, phalanges... Scattered laughter and groans at this embarrassing routine... Cesar's beaten gaze remains riveted to his book. Now he slides a look at the "R-U-DUN" tatt on his right index finger. The severed finger has been sewn back on, supported by a finger brace. Stevie openly stares at the back of Trevor's head as Trevor passes by in the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: AFTER SCHOOL
dialogues.text: RAIN steadily plays AGAINST the WINDOWS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ellen sits behind her computer, lost in a grading program... Trevor now enters. Damp hair and shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: May I come in? Ellen stops what she's working on.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (reticently)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (concerned) Where'd you go the other night?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I was going to ask you the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ++. I went for a run. (changes subject) Wanna get some Chinese later? There's a new place in the Valley Center. '‘Spose to be pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (an excuse) ++. Can't tonight. Maybe another time. Weighs it, and...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (stands there for a moment) .«.. I should probably correct papers anyway. Some of these bungalow kids actually care about a grade. Even Cesar's doing better. Today, for the first time since I took over for Eskander, he actually did his work. (beat) Today Cesar Sanchez was a success. Maybe for the first time in his life. (blinks now) You alright? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: .-. Much better, thank you. A tacit satisfaction that all is well...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-. I really am sorry about Jack. He exits now leaving Ellen alone with her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before school tutoring session. The minute hand on the wall clock jerks ahead one minute... 7:23 AM. Trevor and Rita at a table near the back of the library. Trevor gazes blankly at Rita's essay. Rita revises one of the pages. INTERCUT Dave Childress at the front counter as the librarian (late fifties) photocopies a page from a history book for him. Childress scrutinizes Trevor and Rita as he waits. Satisfied now, Rita slides the page to Trevor...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: ... Finished. Trevor blinks himself back to reality...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: --. Let's hava look.. He adjusts his glasses. Pores over the paper...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ++. Good. (deliberating) .-. I was just thinking, since your essay's about gangs and getting away from their influence, you probably could've left some of those double negatives you like so well.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (confused) So now you wan' me to use bad grammar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (explaining) Only if it suits your topic.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I know. We're all products of our environment 'n' shit.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: No, I think that's just an excuse. (beat) I say if we're strong, we can rise above adversity. (lets it sink in) But it's like rap or hip-hop... Correct all the grammar and it loses its impact.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: So you like hip-hop, Mr. G?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) «+. I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (reacting) What kinda black man are you? Trevor bursts forth a laugh. Childress perks up at the front counter. Trevor's laugh evokes a smile from Rita. Now she pries a little further...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Why you here anyways? Don't you got nothin' better t'do?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. Everything I wanna do is right here. (back on track now) It's a good essay, Rita. You put a lot of effort into it, it shows.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (a laconic grin) Comes from the heart, maestro. I'm a writer... not a fighter. Trevor returns a cognitive flicker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (hinting now) .+. Ms. Quinn was telling me she picks two seniors each year to read their essays at graduation.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (taken aback) She ain't gonna pick my paper. Anyway, I don't wanna get up in fronna all those people and make a fool outta myself.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Why not? It'd be a Pyrrhic victory.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's dat?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... In your case, irony. Refers to King Pyrrhus. Never mind. Look it up sometime. OFF Rita's reluctance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A churning fist of muddy water cuts a path along the perimeter of a golf course and jogging trail. TRACING jogging trail, KEEPING PACE now with a die-hard runner. Something registers in the runner's eyes, pace slowing, now stopping. Not fully comprehending what he is looking at... FOLLOWING HIS GAZE... THROUGH a curtain of rain and tall swamp grass... along the riverbank... TO the base of the Burbank Boulevard Overpass. SLOWING ANGLE to discover precariously jutting out of the rushing waters, in a tangle of chicken wire fence, a partially decomposed torso...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (5TH PERIOD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen walks down an aisle of computers as the class settles... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: .-. Before getting side-tracked with viruses and T-S-R programs, we were talking yesterday about E-Mail. INTERCUT Stevie. Ellen passes Stevie's computer as he shares cryptic information with a kid sitting next to him. Ellen approaches her computer console on wheels at the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: If you click-on the mail icon in your tray, you'll be ready to send and receive mail. My computer's already set-up. Everyone go ahead and click the white envelope in the lower... Ellen's interrupted by her own computer. A little white envelope icon in the lower left hand tray flashes and BEEPS. Now a COMPUTER VOICE announces: "You've got mail." Ellen's taken aback. Class titters. Now she grins.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Looks like someone's way ahead of me. Alright. (adapts and demonstrates ) To retrieve your mail simply double click the top item in your mail list. (as she does) Since we're all a part of the same network, we share mail... so go ahead and do that. The message read: TEACHER FUCKS NIGGERS Class is dumbstruck. Ellen's riveted. Now she turns. Without losing her temper, she scours the class with a narrow gaze. Class starts to buzz. Now a clicking frenzy to retrieve the same message. The anonymous message pops up on computer screens all around the classroom. Ellen's POV of students (and Stevie). Deciphering reactions. LINGERING ON Stevie's poker face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her own poker face now...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Whoever sent that message isn't as anonymous as they think. Ellen turns to her console, clicks the REPLY button. A new mail message window opens up. It's addressed to the anonymous sender, STUDENT #00. Ellen types in:

dialogues.speaker: GO TO THE OFFICE
dialogues.text: All the while anticipation builds on Stevie's face. He glances around, starting to get nervous. Ellen now clicks the SEND button... Stevie's COMPUTER BEEPS... COMPUTER VOICE: "You've got mail..." .-. A window opens in the middle of Stevie's monitor revealing Ellen's return message. Class erupts and Stevie springs out of his seat...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: "Dat's bullshit, man! He rushes up to the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: You best step off, Ms. H. Cuz you can't prove nuthin’. And I know you can't afford to lose ‘dis minimum wage job ‘a yers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (beat and) You're right, Stevie. I can't afford to live in a big house south of the boulevard. Like you do. Class erupts again, coming down on Stevie and his wanna-b poor boy from the streets image. They're laughing at him now, not with him. In a rage, Stevie kicks open the hallway door and exits the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen hastily enters, looking for Stevie. Addresses IRIS (a thirty-something Hispanic woman) behind the counter... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Iris, did Steven Littleton come in here?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Haven't seen ‘im. Teacher #1, the insipid woman, checks her mail slot. It's her conference period.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (appalled) You're not supposed to leave your classroom unattended.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (reacting) Sue me. Teacher #1 exits in a flurry. Ellen now glances to her right. Seated there in rigid silence is BENNY CHACON'S MOTHER (51).

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (offers; sotto) Benny Chacon's mother. Told ‘er Garcia had to leave early today but she jus' sits there. She been saying some pretty crazy things. Mrs. Chacon begins speaking Spanish in plaintive spurts. Ellen can't decipher what she is saying...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Chacon) .+. Espanol, muy poquito, senora. (beat) Mrs. Chacon... you have to slow down. (back to Iris) What's she saying? Hesitating. Now with apprehension...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: You heard ‘bout that body they foun' in the L.A. River... She says she thinks it's Benny. OFF Ellen's unblinking gaze...

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: A concrete fortress... Ellen and Mrs. Chacon approach.  117 118 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen and Mrs. Chacon sit stiffly in front of the ASSISTANT CORONER (mid-forties). Desk cluttered. Half- eaten sandwich in front of him. He nurses a Styrofoam cup of coffee as he flips through a John Doe folder.

dialogues.speaker: ASST. CORONER
dialogues.text: You say he's been missing approximately four weeks?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: .-. Four, almost five weeks.

dialogues.speaker: ASST. CORONER
dialogues.text: That's a long time. Lots a things happen to a body after four or five weeks. Makes it difficult to I.D. A faint, incongruous smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (indicating John Doe) So he just sits here?

dialogues.speaker: ASST. CORONER
dialogues.text: We keep ‘um up to thirty days. Lady, we get 80, sometimes 90 Does a month. Floaters, gangbangers, illegals, junkies. Most of ‘um cheap homicides. Nobody's even lookin' for ‘em. (indicating folder) This guy here, has a dent in his head. Could be post-mortem trauma. Probably hit a retaining wall on his way down river after that rain we had. Who knows. (beat) Yuh ask me, this kid was dead before he got his head caved in. Overdose by morphine. That's what it looks like t'me. Ellen weighs it. Assistant Coroner now refers to some sort of questionnaire.

dialogues.speaker: ASST. CORONER
dialogues.text: On the phone you said the mother mentioned some identifying marks. Ellen refocuses a far-off, introspective gaze. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (affirmative) She said he has some pockmarks on his chest; from a bad case of chicken pox. And there's a bar- code tattoo on his neck. A cognitive flicker now as the Assistant Coroner sets down his coffee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The acrid fecal smell causes Ellen to flinch. Averting her eyes, she holds onto Mrs. Chacon's arm as they stand next to the autopsy table. A plastic diaphanous sheet covers the body. Now the Assistant Coroner raises the sheet... Mrs. Chacon's traumatic gaze confirms her worst fears. She raises a hand to her mouth. Now the tears come...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHACON
dialogues.text: -+. Benito. As she comforts Mrs. Chacon...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (to Assistant Coroner; sotto) Did you find any rosary beads with the body?

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT CORONER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. The digital clock next to Trevor's bed reads: 2:14 a.m. Trevor sleeps. HOLD for a portentous moment. Now the stillness is broken by a CLATTER at the front door. Someone enters the house. Trevor awakens. Jolts out of bed. Disoriented a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In boxer shorts and a T-shirt, adjusting his glasses, Trevor ventures through darkness... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: ... Who's there? A light flickers on in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You should keep your door locked. ADJUSTING the ANGLE now as the living room comes INTO VIEW... Ellen paces back and forth, consumed by what's troubling her.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (still half asleep) What's the matter? Ellen ignores his question.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (impaling him with a look) I just want you to tell me one thing... Now something she sees stops her pacing... «+. The black rosary beads on the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (off Ellen's puzzled look) What? Following her gaze, he picks up the rosary beads. As he places them in a drawer in the credenza.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: What is it? Ellen's confused. Lost in a fixated gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: +. If you had any idea what I've been thinking lately... you'd think I was crazy. (cunning it through her mind) ... Remember that John Doe they found in the L.A. River. Turned out it was Benny. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (impacted) Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: .+. Benny's mother identified the body. Trevor just looks at her, a bated pause. Now he blinks.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Benny was no saint, Ellen. This is a kid who terrorized hald the school. He even broke into your house. Maybe we should think about that ‘fore we shed any tears. Ellen just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: +. Maybe he's better off.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That's a horrible thing to say. Trevor accepts that it is.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Do you believe for every troubled kid like Benny there's one or two others just waiting to take his place? Like Cesar... or his friend Stevie. An awkward moment of silence...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You don't know anything about Cesar's finger, do you, Trevor?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Sometimes a person just runs out of bad choices. Then he's gotta pay a price. What happened to Cesar was inevitable. Ellen flickers a terrified smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You're scaring me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: We make choices in life and we live by 'em. You and I chose to be teachers, to stand on principle. Benny and Cesar, they're takers. They want what they want, and they want it now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Trevor...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (unravelling) I'm sorry but everyone can't always get what they want. Sometimes you gotta take responsibility for your actions. Have you ever been ready to die for a fundamental principle? They haven't. You think those punks would die protecting your Civil Rights?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Trevor, don't.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Did you know Cesar hits his mother? Steals money from her purse? Did you know that? Ellen blanches.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Did you know he was here that night? In the alley?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (confused) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Cesar. Jack was provoked. It wasn't an accident, Ellen. Cesar killed him. Ellen just stares at him. Traumatized...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (momentous deliberation) Where'd you get the rosary beads? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (pause and...) I like you, Ellen. I like you so much. Do you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (riveted) Yes. Trevor can't find words.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: «+. I don't know you. With that, Ellen turns and walks out of the house as quickly as she came.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (plaintively) ++. You do know me. I'ma teacher, just like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CINCO DE MAYO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISH hoardes of cowboy hats, belt sashes and boots as they dance to the loud Mexican band music on the patio... Non-Hispanics, along with non-Quebradita cliques, look on from the lawn area...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: hanging back, on the fringes, scoping out the crowd. Notices a pack of cigarettes in the chest pocket of a 15-year-old kid standing next to him. Kid's wrapped up in talking to another kid, points to something 0O.S.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (to the kid with cigarettes) ++. Don't you know it's not polite to point at people. Everytime you point a finger at someone else... (demonstrates) ... There's three fingers pointing back at you. (lesson over) Lemme have a cigarette.  122 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/22/96 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. Cinco de Mayo. The sounds of a QUEBRADITA waft in from outside in the quad. At the same time, Steve follows him into the rest room. They're all alone.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Eh, Mr. G? Bracing himself with a fixed, straight-ahead look.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (boldly) I'm talkin' ta you, Garfield. (beat) Know what you did to Cesar. (wild notion) -+. I'm thinkin' maybe you did Benny, too. (incredulously) That possible? You crush my friend's skull? Fuck ‘im up wit' a two-by-four, maybe a baseball bat? No response. As Trevor starts to leave, Stevie blocks his path. Trevor steps to one side to go around... but Stevie blocks his path again.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (trying to maintain) Please, step out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: -+- You kill my friend? Huh? Trevor's head begins to swim. His life's falling apart. Like a trapped animal, he back-pedals a step to escape... but then suddenly snaps. He explodes into Stevie, crushing him against the bath- room wall. Trevor impales Stevie with a look that says it all. Stevie immediately shrinks. Trevor now blinks. Cooling himself down. Slowing his breathing. Stevie slips out from under his hold and bolts for the exit.  123 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/22/96 98A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cesar and his tag-bangers... Cesar holds court, drowned out by the MUSIC. Now Stevie arrives. Out of breath. Urgent to tell his story. Rita... Makeup subdued, wearing a cotton button-down blou She watches the Quebradita from behind a tree. A desire to be part of it, she moves a little closer... ++. as Cesar notices her. His head races from Stevie's news. Eyes penetrating. Now galvanized. On a rampage, he shoves his way through the crowd. Victor Sifuentes... on the opposite side of the patio, snapping a look, spotting Cesar moving in for the kill. With a start, Victor barks something into his walkie- talkie and squeezes his way into the Quebradita crowd... Cesar shoves Rita to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: School girl bitch! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rita gets to her feet immediately...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (shaken) You gotta problem?!

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Yer fuckin' maestro, ‘at's my problem!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't know what yer talkin' ‘bout!

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Garfield killed Benny! Rita looks at him like he's insane. Cesar's entourage gathers around them.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yer crazy. She turns her back and starts to leave. Cesar grabs her again...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Don't turn yer back on me when I'm talkin' t'you, bitch. You think yer better than everybody else. Well you ain't! You ain't nuthin' but a whore!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Fuck you, asshole!

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: What? You forget about the time in the bungalows? We all had our turn wit you, man!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (gets in her face) What the fuck you been fuckin' a nigger for? Huh? You think he's gonna protec' you? Stop me from doin' whatever I want wit' you? Stop any of us from doin' what we want wit' you?! Rita just stands there, destroyed and sobbing now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Cesar.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: No, fuck you! He grabs her blouse and rips it wide open. His eyes glisten with fervor now as he punches Rita (with his good hand) square in the face. She crumbles to the ground as Victor bursts through the crowd and restrains Cesar. As Rita gets to her feet and flees into the Quebradita crowd...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Garfield better watch his back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing room only. An impassioned crowd.

dialogues.speaker: ANGLO WOMAN
dialogues.text: .-. I wanna know if this boy was killed and whether it was gang- related. The audience erupts in unanimous support...

dialogues.speaker: ANGLO WOMAN
dialogues.text: (playing to crowd now) As a mother and a taxpayer, I have a right to know. And if it was gang-related then I want tighter security... At this point she's drowned out by the crowd. On stage the discipline committee, including Trevor, Childress, Hyland and Quinn sit at the dais. Garcia stands at the podium, waiting for silence. MRS. FORD, the assistant principal, a full-figured black woman in her mid-fifties, stands alongside him, gesturing for the crowd to settle down.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: The death... (too noisy) The death of Benito Chacon is not gang-related. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's something you heard on the news. It's wrong. It's misinformation.

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: (shouting out) Who says? How can you be so sure? You're talking about my kid's safety.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: Please, everyone just calm down. Audience settles.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Ford. (now) «+. The police at this point aren't even sure if it's a case of murder. The reason we're having this meeting tonight is to quash all the rumors floating around out there. Okay. Here's what we do know. Benny Chacon ultimately died from a drug overdose, technically it was morphine. (volume rising again) Which is what heroin breaks down into...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .-. Dat's bullshit! Benny was no junkie! I know who did it! Heads turn... .-+. Ellen quietly enters now and stands just inside one of the doors at the back of the hall... Up at the dais, Trevor notices her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: It's not the gangbangers y'gotta worry about. It's the teachers!

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: That's exactly the type of rumor we don't need, Mr. Littleton. Stevie deliberately stands and points at Trevor with vitriol in his eyes... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: --+. It was Garfield. The audience grows silent.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: (losing his patience) Say one more word and you're suspended.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: +. Sit down, Stevie. Trevor doesn't even flinch. Childress scrutinizes him with a glance.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (ranting) You're a fuckin' murderer, Garfield!

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: (calling for assistance) Victor?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: «+. Maybe I can't prove it but I know he did it. He fucked up Cesar and he killed Benny. (to crowd) Ast ‘im! As Victor and another plainclothes cop attempt to remove Stevie...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Touch me and I'll sue yer ass! (as Victor backs off; now to Trevor) Yer dead, G! Yer a dead man! With that Stevie shoves Victor aside and bolts for the door. Garcia attempts to regain his composure... Trevor glances back to the spot where Ellen was standing... but now she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeting's broken up. Dave Childress, cigarette dangling from his mouth, jogs a step to catch up with Trevor... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Garfield, wait up... Trevor maintains a steady pace, one hopeful eye scouring the parking lot for Ellen...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: +. Don't let that Littleton punk get to you. Trevor ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Lil' bastard's a tweaker. He's a speed freak. You didn't know that? At Trevor's car now. Hesitating. Turning to Childress...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (testing his patience) What is it, Dave? How can I help you? Unintentionally in Trevor's face...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: How ‘bout a ride? (taking a step back) .-+. The wife wouldn't let me drive my own car. Ain't that a bitch? Childress is pitiful. Wears a grease-stained tie with his wrinkled Hawaiian shirt and a Windbreaker.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (with resignation) ++. You smell like beer.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: I only had two. That's all. Swear ta Christ. Raising his palms. Surrendering. Trevor studies him with a sad grimace.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: I live right up here off Chandler. I'll buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave's Sanctuary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At the end of a gravel driveway, behind a darkened house. Garage door open. Childress chain smokes and drinks beer as he leans against the dented fender of his '66 Lincoln Continental. Trevor nurses a Diet Coke...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: --. I had the same situation ‘round the time of that 'Night Stalker' thing. Remember that? Whole city was scared shitless. My wife was convinced the frickin' mailman was the 'Stalker' for about a week there. (a tubercular chuckle) Some mental giant in my 4th period starts this rumor, see. Childress is the 'Night Stalker.' Right? (chug-a-lugs) .+. Idiots. Even after they caught that Ramirez jerk, I'd still hear those fucks '... They got the wrong guy. Childress is the Stalker, ese.' He finishes beer. Crumples it. Trevor studies him, without expression. Now he notices something stapled to the tar paper wall... Trevor's POV of the "Certificate of Excellence in Teaching," yellowed and dogeared, hanging obliquely by one staple. .»+. as Childress opens another beer.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (excusing himself) I better get goin'. Thanks for the soda.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Wait, wait. Hold your horses. Just hold on... ... Finding a key in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (a twisted grin) -+. Can't leave without meetin' the kids. Childress unlocks a particle board cabinet against the garage wall. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A watery glint in his bloodshot eyes. Cabinet door swings wide now, revealing a mini arsenal of handguns...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Ta-dah... Huh? Trevor's eyes remain expressionless. Childress rhapsodizes as he removes and handles some of the guns...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: -.. This one's from Czechoslovakia. It's a C-Z .22 automatic. Ten round clip. Glow- in-the-dark sights. (eyeing the sights) Ain't that a beauty? (next) --. Then we gotta custom Smitty, 9 ‘milli.' With extended grip. These Smith & Wessons kick like a mutha. (and next) Now this one's special. A Glock 21. Lightest gun in the world. The barrel and firing pin are metal. See. Everything else on it's plastic. (handing it to Trevor) Here, feel that. Trevor takes it, reluctantly weighs it in the palm of his hand. Sets it down. Now Childress removes a gun from a holster in the small of his back, under his Windbreaker...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: ... ‘Course you can never be too prepared. My pukey 1lil' Davis 380.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (a severe squint) You wear that thing at school?

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (a smirk) .+. Don't worry. They never use metal detectors on teachers. (beat) I also keep a .357 inside my desk. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a wry grin) ... But you already know that. Didn't think I was payin' attention, did'ja? Shoulda seen the look on your face. Pretending now. Aiming the .380 at an imaginary student...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Now, Jose, if I've told you once I've told you a hundred times, stay in your cotton pickin' seat. (aiming gun) Boom! Childress laughs and chokes on his cigarette. Now he gazes at the .380 in his hand. Lost in a stupid, recalcitrant grin...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: Haven't you ever just wanted to blow one of these little bastards away? Childress glances up into Trevor's unflinching gaze. Smiles to himself now. Thinks he's funny...

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (digressing) -+. Speaking of blowing, you ever wanna fuck a high school girl, Garfield? (off no response) ‘Caught yer girl, Rita, bustin' a train out in the ‘utility' shed couple months back. Swear to God. She had at least five or six cholos lined up back there. (as Trevor's eyes narrow) Face it, brother, she's a slut. c'mon, I know you had ‘er. (bragging now) I even did her.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You're drunk.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: I know you been laughin' at me behind my back. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' about screwin' high school broads and you're givin' off this self-righteous attitude like your shit don't stink. Childress rolls back on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: .-.- Tell me the truth now, Garfield. Did yuh do it? C'mon, I won't tell. Did yuh whack Benny? Whadda ‘bout Cesar? That was generous, only taking his finger. I woulda cut off his balls.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-»-- Go to hell, Dave. All traces of a smile fade from Dave's face. Trevor just stands there. Doesn't say a damn word. Childress makes his own momentous conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDRESS
dialogues.text: (almost exulted) You really did it. You son of a bitch. Awkward glint of admiration in Childress's eye. Leans forward, hangs a hand on Trevor's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (disgusted) You probably think you and me are alike. Trevor turns and exits the garage. PULLING BACK FROM Childress's dull anesthetized gaze. Deep down inside Childress knows he's a pathetic piece of shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor pulls into his driveway, right up to the garage door. He SHUTS OFF the IGNITION and narrows a gaze out the front windshield...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Caught in his headlights, tagged all over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Spray painted threats like, "YOU'RE DEAD," "187-UM," "TEACHER-K" (crossed out) and a CARTOON VERSION OF TREVOR WITH "X'S" WHERE HIS EYES ARE SUPPOSED TO BE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dimly lit. Trevor stands in front of the television set, staring at a late-night repeat of "Talk Soup."

dialogues.speaker: TALK SOUP
dialogues.text: A clip from "Sally Jessy Rafael" or "Jerry Springer." One of those Sturm und Drang moments. Everyone points the finger at everyone else. No one willing to take responsibility for themselves. Only partially watching the television. His eyes are fixed on a point somewhere in his own mind, lost to the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BEFORE SCHOOL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into a parabolic mirror above the library doors... «+. an empty corridor stretches forever. Trevor, now unshaven, looking like he hasn't slept, sits amidst total silence in his regular spot. No sign of Rita. He checks his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: WALL CLOCK
dialogues.text: reads... 7:10 AM.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: peering toward the library doors. Nothing. Now above the doors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK AND FORTH between the mirror and Trevor. His eyes glazed and unblinking. FURTHER INTO the parabolic mirror now. Breathing becoming more and more labored. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In a flicker, we're transported back to Roosevelt Whitney... Dennis Broadway's image SLOWLY COMING TOWARD us down the long corridor...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Trevor catches his breath and blinks... .+. Back to reality. The mirror is empty. He removes his Proventil inhaler from his shirt pocket. Suppressing gasps, he takes two hits. Two girls at the magazine racks whisper to each other, eyes firmly fixed on Trevor. Suddenly there's a presence at Trevor's side...

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: .»+. I don't think she's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strictly low rent district. The small dirt yard in front is contained within a cinder block wall. Rita, back to her chola look, heavy makeup, black (right) eye where Cesar punched her, watches her two younger brothers as they fight over a toy truck. Her three-year-old baby sister, Maricella (too big to be carried) straddles her hip as Rita yells at the boys...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Be nice to your brother, Antonio. Don't make me go get Mommie. Trevor's car pulls up. Rita's taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (setting Maricella down ) Go play wit' your brothers. Rita attempts to thwart him at the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (almost defensive) Whatcha doin' here, maestro? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (with fervor) I want you to come back to school, Rita. You can't afford to miss finals. They won't let you graduate.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (overlapping) No way. Forget it. I can't. What's wrong wit' you. Trevor really does looks like hell.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (beseeching her) Cesar and Stevie won't bother you. That's a promise. Something stirs deep inside her.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (struggles with it) Why'd they have to kill Snowball?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: «+. They didn't.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (on the verge of tears now) What's it fuckin' matter?! ‘At school shit's for other kids, not me!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: That's not true. You're so smart, Rita. Don't you know that? You have an opportunity here to change your life. Please don't throw away everything we've worked for. Trevor just stares at her, incredulously. Rita lowers her gaze, unable to look him in the eye. Momentous deliberation, and now...

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I know what happened with Childress.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (knitting her eyebrows ) What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (beat) He won't ever touch you again.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (protesting too much) He ain't done nuthin' tuh me. That boy's fulla shit. What's he been sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: He ain't never touched me no ways. What's he sayin'? He say he fucked me?! He say dat?! (off Trevor's look) He's a damn liar! (erupting again; tears streaming down her face) Get the fuck outta here! I don't need yer damn pity and I don't need you!

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (genuinely) But I need you, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (hardening) You made a mistake. Dat's all. With that Rita scoops up Maricella and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor sits transfixed in front of Garcia. Still hasn't shaven.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: See these? Garcia holds up a handful of phone messages.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: They're phone calls about you. Good ones. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cesar's mother told me how you tried to help him. You're evidently a good teacher. You should be commended on your efforts. However... (pause) I'm going to have to let you go. Trevor blinks.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: (beat) As much as I'd like to have you stay until the end of the year, I can't overlook the seriousness of certain accusations. Mr. Garcia waits for a response but none is forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: (for example) .-. Is it true you had meetings with a female student at your house?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I was trying to help her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GARCIA
dialogues.text: The implications are still there, Mr. Garfield. I can't afford to open the door for another lawsuit. Sure you can appreciate my position. (pause) You can stay until Friday. I hope that will be sufficient. This part registers only minimally with Trevor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VAPID SILENCE HOLDS us. The bungalow is awash in a sun-soaked pool of light... Trevor makes his way toward the parking lot with his briefcase and a cardboard box of personal belongings.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER LAB
dialogues.text: Plagued with doubts, Ellen lingers in the doorway, confiding with Hyland... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: You're not being an alarmist. (minimizing her concerns ) He gets a little overzealous at times... like some other people I know. (beat) I don't think the rosary adds up to much either, frankly.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: It's probably his. (beat) Look, when I received my first Holy Communion all the boys got black rosaries and the girls got white. Trust me, there must be millions of black rosaries filed away in desk drawers from here to the Vatican. Ellen flickers a sad indecisive smile.

dialogues.speaker: HYLAND
dialogues.text: This guy's been through a lot, Ellen. The system failed him. I don't think any of us can really appreciate what he's been through. (beat) I say we give the man a break. Ellen acquiesces a pensive nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH a CHAIN LINK FENCE Trevor approaches his car. Traffic is bumper to bumper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ++. as Trevor unlocks his car. And hesitates. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER'S SIDE CAR DOOR
dialogues.text: ++. a bold 187 has been "keyed" into the paint.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Rivetted. Now he slides the cardboard box, along with his briefcase onto the front seat. Suddenly, as if out of nowhere, Ellen pulls up in her Cherokee. She deciphers Trevor with mixed emotions. Trevor adjusts his stance, covering the "187." Ellen now tentatively rolls her window down halfway... TAILPIPE SPUTTERS, a portentous idle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (stilted) «+. I'd like to apologize for the other night. Trevor stands there transfixed for a moment. Now he looks into her eyes. A soulful gaze.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Shouldn't listen to me. I was half asleep. His eyes become damp. Trevor smiles bravely.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We really need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: .-. Not tonight. Have to finish some work...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow then? It's important to me.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: (far off now) «+. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (resolves it in her head) -+. How ‘bout seven o'clock? Trevor nods. Ellen flickers a tenuous smile.  139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «++. aS she rolls up her window and drives away, leaving Trevor standing in the middle of the parking lot. His image gets smaller and smaller in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she watches him in the side view mirror, torn with mixed emotions.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 140
dialogues.text: thru 143

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing now that the whole house has been tagged with graffiti (not only the garage) as the Rambler pulls into the driveway. With dead calm, Trevor leaves his box of belongings behind and enters the front door, carrying his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: ++. aS it parks about two houses down from Trevor's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three tag-bangers produce firearms... Cesar loads the cylinder chamber on his .357 magnum. Stevie double checks a 7 round clip and a 39 Smith and Wesson. And Paco plays with a .38 caliber revolver that he hides in the deep front pocket of is County-Bens. The interior of the Buick snaps with the hard sound of gun metal... cocking hammers, loading cartridges and spinning cylinder chambers... .-. As the gun preparations systematically stop. Cesar now flicks ON an ELECTRIC HAIR CLIPPER, sets it on 'NO CLIP,' and passes it back to Paco. Paco runs the clipper over his head. Hair tumbles off in chunks. Stevie fidgets, picks up a naked one-eyed doll off the floor, raises it INTO VIEW...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Where'd you jack ‘dis car from, homes? (veferring to doll) ‘At's nasty, man.  146

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutifully seated at his desk. Like a fervent prayer. Lost in correcting his final graded assignment.

dialogues.speaker: SUNSET 146A
dialogues.text: PAST wrought iron bars on the outside of the window. Sun hangs above a distorted horizon.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SUNSET 146B
dialogues.text: ... PAST high tension lines outside Mother Henry's kitchen window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen's preoccupied with thought as she rinses dishes and places them in the dishwasher. 0.S. hear "WHEEL OF FORTUNE" on the TELEVISION. Now a wet DISH slips from her grasp and SHATTERS on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ellen? As she picks up the pieces...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: --. It's alright, mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun goes down. A palpable stillness permeates.

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: All three heads clipped "skin tight." Fixed gazes holding. Stevie nurses a runny nose as he smokes another "Sherm." Now something flickers in Cesar's eyes...

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: «+. Okay, let's smoke this bitch.  150 151 1 8 7 - Rev. 9/4/96 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is quiet now as Stevie and Paco disappear around the back. Cesar approaches the front door, undaunted, gun drawn. Without breaking stride he kicks open the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trevor sits on his bed, watching the red orb of the sun disappear over the horizon. He can hear DOOR OPENING and someone moving in his house.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I'm in here, Cesar. Cesar, Paco, and Stevie enter the bedroom, guns drawn.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
