dialogues.text: Dont' move, mutha fucka! Stevie flips on a light. Paco SHOOTS out the TV set in the living room -- an act of intimidation. Cesar jams his .357 under Trevor's chin. Gets in his face.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: You killed Benny. And you cut off my finger... Say it. Trevor stares right into Cesar's eyes, unflinching.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. I did.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Told yuh. Fuckin' A, man.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Lemme do ‘im.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: No. This nigga's mine. Cesar sticks the gun barrel right between Trevor's eyes «+. and squeezes the trigger. Click. An empty sound. Trevor blinks. Cesar exhales a malicious laugh. Opens a fist to reveal six bullets.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Ever seen The Deerhunter, ese?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of the dark house -- Trevor's dining room table. Trevor on one side, Cesar/Paco/Stevie on the other. Cesar's seated, loading one of the six bullets into a cylinder chamber. He shoves the gun toward Trevor as Stevie and Paco train their pistols on him.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: You gon' do yourself, mayate. Put it to your head and pull the trigger. Trevor grabs the pistol without hesitation, puts it to his head and squeezes off TWO ROUNDS without incident. He slams the gun down in front of Cesar without a blink. A crazed, watery glint in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: That macho enough for you, Cesar? Huh? That make me a man?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Take more'n that.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Then you do it. All three tag-bangers are taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: C'mon, show me what you got. Mano a mano.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: He's playin' with yer head.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Vato's scared. He tryin' to twist outta it.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I gotta be a fool to prove you're a fool? -- okay. Trevor picks up the gun again, puts it to his head and pulls the trigger... click. Slams the gun down.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Tha's not how we playin' it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Why -- you too chickenshit to play yer own game? Got no cojones? Paco lashes out and hits Trevor with his pistol drawing blood.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Shut up! Cesar stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You gonna let your homies defend your punk ass, Cesar? You gonna let me dis you? I pulled three times, you pussy, you leva, you coward! Lessee you pull one. C'mon, be a man! Get some respect back! Do it! Cesar takes the gun and raises it toward his head.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Whatcho doin', homie? He grabs Cesar's arm, but Cesar pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: (to Trevor) You disrespectin' me, vato? You sayin' I ain't a man?

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: I'm sayin' you're a fool. Cesar puts the .357 to his temple again...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Don't do it! They are mesmerized into inaction as Cesar grits his teet and pulls the trigger. Click.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: (instant adulation) You the man, Cesar! You the man! Orale, vato! (to Trevor) He got character, homes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Crazy mutha fucka. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Trevor looks at Cesar in disgust as he takes another bullet and blindly loads it into the cylinder chamber.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: Yer turn. He spins the cylinder and slams the gun on the table.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You think you got respect now? Your kinda respect is bullshit. Only thing you honor is stupidity. You ready to die for stupidity, Cesar? I am, if it'll teach you somethin'. See you can't kill me, homeboy. Yeah, my body... but what I am, who I was? That's been dead for over a year. And I'm never gonna get it back -- no matter how many of you I get rid of. I realize that now... (furious) --. Iwas a teacher! I wanted to help you!... He snatches up the gun, puts it to his head and pulls the trigger again... click. Trevor slams it back down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: You can't kill me... and you can't scare me. Cesar's sweating now, glancing between Trevor and the gun on the table. Stevie and Paco shift uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Don't do it, homie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: He's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, but isn't that what you respect? Bein' loco? Don't listen to ‘em, Cesar. If you gonna live stupid don't do it half-assed -- take it all the way. Take your turn. Pull the trigger. Caught between the proverbial rock and a hard place, Cesar's hand inches toward the gun. Suddenly Trevor is screaming at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Macho is bullshit, fool! Your whol y of Bi HIT! Cesar explodes to his feet and screams right back.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: It's all I got! Silence. Trevor studies him with an enigmatic look.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR
dialogues.text: Well then, I'll take your turn for you... He snatches up the pistol and puts it to his head..

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: No! --. pulls the trigger. BLAM!! The SHOT knocks Trevor out of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 152
dialogues.text: thru thru

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: He's He's out! You see dat! Snuffed hisself! fuckin' out! Aw, shit! Stevie's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What'd he do that for? He walks toward the back of the house like a zombie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: .-. Let's get outta here. Paco pulls at Cesar, who's staring at Trevor's dead body.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: C'mon, homie.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: He took my turn. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: --. What?

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: It was my turn. He took it... He dissed me.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: So fuckin' what, man! He's dead! Let's go! Cesar shrugs him off, picks up the .357.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: I gotta do this.

dialogues.speaker: PACO
dialogues.text: Fuck dis shit! Leave it! He tries to pull Cesar away, pleading with him in Spanish but Cesar shoves him off.

dialogues.speaker: CESAR
dialogues.text: I got one chance in six. I'm ‘onna beat ‘dis bitch... For honor, vato.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: No!! Paco rushes toward him, but is stopped by the BOOM! of the .357. Frozen in shock, Paco stares down at Cesar's body as Stevie re-enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Cesar?... Why'd he do it? Why?

dialogues.speaker: 167B ON PACO AND STEVIE 167B
dialogues.text: Not knowing himself, Paco stumbles out of Trevor's kitchen toward the back door. Finally Stevie follows him as we PULL BACK to reveal the crumpled bodies of Trevor and Cesar lying on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-. Last night tragedy struck in North Hollywood where a high school teacher and one of his students were both found shot to death inside the teacher's home. V.O. continues through the...  168

dialogues.speaker: 168A
dialogues.text: makeshift stage. etc... 7 - Rev. 9/4/96

dialogues.speaker: TWO WEEKS LATER
dialogues.text: «+. the marquee outside the school reads...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... The teacher has been identified as forty-one-year-old Trevor Garfield, formerly of New York City. Most recently he taught science at John Quincy Adams High School in the San Fernando Valley... (beat) Confidential sources reveal that the teacher had publicly been accused of foul play in the death of another student whose body was discovered just last month in the L.A. River...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graduation in progress. Standing room only. Administrators have begun to take their seats up on a Garcia, Hyland, Assistant Principal 122A. 168

dialogues.speaker: 168A
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1 8 7 - Rev. 7/11/96 122B. CONTINUED: (Al) 168A Bleachers now as guests and family members fan themselves against the searing heat. A banner strung across the top row of seats reads...

dialogues.speaker: CONGRATULATIONS CLASS OF '97
dialogues.text: Faculty members are seated in the first two rows down on the field. In front of a sea of mortar boards. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dave Childress now enters, his usual shabby attire, nursing another hangover. He takes a seat away from the other teachers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the first speaker approaches the podium.. ON two inch high heels, an occasional wobble as the white high heels make their way up to the podium. ANGLE RISING now, LINGERING ON a clinging powder blue dress and mani- cured fingernails. HOLD ON her clenched essay. Now CONTINUE UP to reveal Rita Nartinez. She wears lipstick... and only a moderate amount of eye shadow. She wears a slightly nervous, preoccupied look. Now... Rita at the podium, as she adjusts the microphone, a nervous reflex. Places her essay on the podium. Stares down at it...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: .-. The title of my essay is, ‘Mi Vida Loca'... 'My Crazy Life'... Rita hesitates. Now she gazes out at the graduating class.

dialogues.speaker: FACES IN CROWD 168C
dialogues.text: Waiting... Intently fanning themselves...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE CHILDRESS 168D
dialogues.text: Apathetic. Arms draped over the empty chairs on either side of him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (turning to Quinn) Ms. Quinn, can I say somethin'? (correcting herself) .»+. May I say something? Ms. Quinn (45) hesitates, now acquiesces with uncertainty... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: -.+. There's been a lotta talk las' couple weeks whether Mr. Garfield done those things they been writin’ about in the newspaper. He once tol' me you can't blame everything on yer environment. (beat) But I t'ink you can push a good teacher too far and he might jus' go bad like anybody else... 169 thru 172

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT VARIOUS CUTS OF Ellen's hands as she clears a bulletin board... removes a computer graphics display fro a wall... empties desk drawers... and packs away her computer in a box.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ++. I dunno if Mr. 'G' did all those bad things. All I know is dat teachers don't get no respect. ‘At's the simple truth. And if Mr. 'G' is responsible, well den he ain't the only one responsible...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: .+. We're all responsible. You and me... all of us. I'm up here today cuz a him. He was dere for me when nobody else was. Thing is... I shoulda been ‘dere for him too... but I wasn't. I turned my back on the only person who ever cared about me. (pause) He said if I could stand up here and read my essay it would be a Pyrrhic victory. (beat) I ast' ‘im, ‘What's up wit’ dat?' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A trickle of incongruous laughter, awkward yet cathartic...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: He told me in my case it was irony... and to go look it up... so I did. (beat) I wonder now if Mr. 'G' was really talking ‘bout hisself. (beat) It refers to this guy named Pyrrhus. He was a king back ‘round 300 B.C. Rita refers to a piece of scratch paper she has tucked inside her essay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: again... as she now empties one last drawer, she dis- covers her teaching credential. Reluctantly picks it up. Holds it for a moment. Now read across the face of the credential...

dialogues.speaker: COMMISSION ON TEACHER CREDENTIALING
dialogues.text: issues this document to

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (verbatim now) ... Pyrrhus defeated the Romans on two occasions. But those two victories lost him a large part of his army. Now whenever people say something's a Pyrrhic victory they mean it's a victory gained at too great a cost. Childress stares off into space, flickers a pathetic smir And now Stevie seated amongst the graduates. Glancing up from under his mortar board cap. He adjusts a gaze into the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: HIS PARENTS 175B
dialogues.text: Early forties, upper-middle class. Stevie's mother catches his eye. Like an incongruous SLOW MOTION dream, she mouth the words, "Were... So... Proud... Of... You."

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE LITTLETON 175C
dialogues.text: -+. aS guilt eats at him, weaving its insidious web.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RITA 175D
dialogues.text: now at the podium. Holding back tears, Rita now carefully folds up her piece of scratch paper... and fixes a distan unblinking gaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+. Slowly SCAN the walls, stripped completely bare now. END ON Ellen standing obliquely in the doorway. Brief- case in hand, files and papers tucked under one arm. Her face, a solemn vacuous gaze. Now she drops something into the trash can, shuts off the lights, and leaves. As the door slowly closes...
